Complexity and Approximation of Fixing Numerical Attributes in Databases Under Integrity Constraints††thanks: Dedicated to the memory of Alberto Mendelzon. Our research on this topic started with conversations between Loreto Bravo and him. Alberto was always generous with his time, advice and ideas; our community is already missing him very much.

Leopoldo Bertossi       Loreto Bravo
Carleton University    School of Computer Science    Ottawa    Canada.
             {bertossi    lbravo}@scs.carleton.ca
Enrico Franconi       Andrei Lopatenko
Free University of Bozen–Bolzano Also: University of Manchester, Department of Computer Science, UK.    Faculty of Computer Science    Italy.
{franconi    lopatenko}@inf.unibz.it
Abstract

Consistent query answering is the problem of computing the answers from a database that are consistent with respect to certain integrity constraints that the database as a whole may fail to satisfy. Those answers are characterized as those that are invariant under minimal forms of restoring the consistency of the database. In this context, we study the problem of repairing databases by fixing integer numerical values at the attribute level with respect to denial and aggregation constraints. We introduce a quantitative definition of database fix, and investigate the complexity of several decision and optimization problems, including DFP, i.e. the existence of fixes within a given distance from the original instance, and CQA, i.e. deciding consistency of answers to aggregate conjunctive queries under different semantics. We provide sharp complexity bounds, identify relevant tractable cases; and introduce approximation algorithms for some of those that are intractable. More specifically, we obtain results like undecidability of existence of fixes for aggregation constraints; MAXSNP-hardness of DFP, but a good approximation algorithm for a relevant special case; and intractability but good approximation for CQA for aggregate queries for one database atom denials (plus built-ins).

1 Introduction

Integrity constraints (ICs) are used to impose semantics on a database with the purpose of making the database an accurate model of an application domain. Database management systems or application programs enforce the satisfaction of the ICs by rejecting undesirable updates or executing additional compensating actions. However, there are many situations where we need to interact with databases that are inconsistent in the sense that they do not satisfy certain desirable ICs. In this context, an important problem in database research consists in characterizing and retrieving consistent data from inconsistent databases [5], in particular consistent answers to queries. From the logical point of view, consistently answering a query posed to an inconsistent database amounts to evaluating the truth of a formula against a particular class of first-order structures [3], as opposed to the usual process of truth evaluation in a single structure (the relational database).

Certain database applications, like census, demographic, financial, and experimental data, contain quantitative data, usually associated to nominal or qualitative data, e.g. number of children associated to a household identification code (or address); or measurements associated to a sample identification code. Usually this kind of data contains errors or mistakes with respect to certain semantic constraints. For example, a census form for a particular household may be considered incorrect if the number of children exceeds 20; or if the age of a parent is less than 10. These restrictions can be expressed with denial integrity constraints, that prevent some attributes from taking certain values [11]. Other restrictions may be expressed with aggregation ICs, e.g. the maximum concentration of certain toxin in a sample may not exceed a certain specified amount; or the number of married men and married women must be the same. Inconsistencies in numerical data can be resolved by changing individual attribute values, while keeping values in the keys, e.g. without changing the household code, the number of children is decreased considering the admissible values.

We consider the problem of fixing integer numerical data wrt certain constraints while (a) keeping the values for the attributes in the keys of the relations, and (b) minimizing the quantitative global distance between the original and modified instances. Since the problem may admit several global solutions, each of them involving possibly many individual changes, we are interested in characterizing and computing data and properties that remain invariant under any of these fixing processes. We concentrate on denial and aggregation constraints; and conjunctive queries, with or without aggregation.

Database repairs have been studied in the context of consistent query answering (CQA), i.e. the process of obtaining the answers to a query that are consistent wrt a given set of ICs [3] (c.f. [5] for a survey). There, consistent data is characterized as invariant under all minimal forms of restoring consistency, i.e. as data that is present in all minimally repaired versions of the original instance (the repairs). Thus, an answer to a query is consistent if it can be obtained as a standard answer to the query from every possible repair. In most of the research on CQA, a repair is a new instance that satisfies the given ICs, but differs from the original instance by a minimal set, under set inclusion, of (completely) deleted or inserted tuples. Changing the value of a particular attribute can be modelled as a deletion followed by an insertion, but this may not correspond to a minimal repair. However, in certain applications it may make more sense to correct (update) numerical values only in certain attributes. This requires a new definition of repair that considers: (a) the quantitative nature of individual changes, (b) the association of the numerical values to other key values; and (c) a quantitative distance between database instances.

Example 1

Consider a network traffic database D𝐷Ditalic_D that stores flow measurements of links in a network. This network has two types of links, labelled 00 and 1111, with maximum capacities 1000100010001000 and 1500150015001500, resp.

Traffic Time Link Type Flow
1.1 a 0 1100
1.1 b 1 900
1.3 b 1 850

Database D𝐷Ditalic_D is inconsistent wrt this IC. Under the tuple and set oriented semantics of repairs [3], there is a unique repair, namely deleting tuple 𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐(1.1,a,0,{\it Traffic}(1.1,a,0,italic_Traffic ( 1.1 , italic_a , 0 , 1100)1100)1100 ). However, we have two options that may make more sense than deleting the flow measurement, namely updating the violating tuple to 𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐(1.1,a,0,{\it Traffic}(1.1,a,0,italic_Traffic ( 1.1 , italic_a , 0 , 1000)1000)1000 ) or to 𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐⁢(1.1,a,1,1100)𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐1.1𝑎11100{\it Traffic}(1.1,a,1,1100)italic_Traffic ( 1.1 , italic_a , 1 , 1100 ); satisfying an implicit requirement that the numbers should not change too much. □□\Box□

Update-based repairs for restoring consistency are studied in [25]; where changing values in attributes in a tuple is made a primitive repair action; and semantic and computational problems around CQA are analyzed from this perspective. However, peculiarities of changing numerical attributes are not considered, and more importantly, the distance between databases instances used in [25, 26] is based on set-theoretic homomorphisms, but not quantitative, as in this paper. In [25] the repaired instances are called fixes, a term that we keep here (instead of repairs), because our basic repair actions are also changes of (numerical) attribute values. In this paper we consider fixable attributes that take integer values and the quadratic, Euclidean distance L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT between database instances. Specific fixes and approximations may be different under other distance functions, e.g. the “city distance” L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (the sum of absolute differences), but the general (in)tractability and approximation results remain. However, moving to the case of real numbers will certainly bring new issues that require different approaches; they are left for ongoing and future research. Actually it would be natural to investigate them in the richer context of constraint databases [18].

The problem of attribute-based correction of census data forms is addressed in [11] using disjunctive logic programs with stable model semantics. Several underlying and implicit assumptions that are necessary for that approach to work are made explicit and used here, extending the semantic framework of [11].

We provide semantic foundations for fixes that are based on changes on numerical attributes in the presence of key dependencies and wrt denial and aggregate ICs, while keeping the numerical distance to the original database to a minimum. This framework introduces new challenging decision and optimization problems, and many algorithmic and complexity theoretic issues. We concentrate in particular on the “Database Fix Problem” (DFP), of determining the existence of a fix at a distance not bigger than a given bound, in particular considering the problems of construction and verification of such a fix. These problems are highly relevant for large inconsistent databases. For example, solving DFP can help us find the minimum distance from a fix to the original instance; information that can be used to prune impossible branches in the process of materialization of a fix. The CQA problem of deciding the consistency of query answers is studied wrt decidability, complexity, and approximation under several alternative semantics.

We prove that DFP and CQA become undecidable in the presence of aggregation constraints. However, DFP is NP-complete for linear denials, which are enough to capture census like applications. CQA belongs to Π2PsubscriptsuperscriptΠ𝑃2\Pi^{P}_{2}roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and becomes Δ2PsubscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑃2\Delta^{P}_{2}roman_Δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-hard, but for a relevant class of denials we get tractability of CQA to non aggregate queries, which is again lost with aggregate queries. Wrt approximation, we prove that DFP is 𝑀𝐴𝑋𝑆𝑁𝑃𝑀𝐴𝑋𝑆𝑁𝑃{\it MAXSNP}italic_MAXSNP-hard in general, and for a relevant subclass of denials we provide an approximation within a constant factor that depends on the number of atoms in them. All the algorithmic and complexity results, unless otherwise stated, refer to data complexity [2], i.e. to the size of the database that here includes a binary representation for numbers. For complexity theoretic definitions and classical results we refer to [21].

This paper is structured as follows. Section 2 introduces basic definitions. Sections 3 presents the notion of database fix, several notions of consistent answer to a query; and some relevant decision problems. Section 4 investigates their complexity. In Section 5 approximations for the problem of finding the minimum distance to a fix are studied, obtaining negative results for the general case, but good approximation for the class of local denial constraints. Section 6 investigates tractability of CQA for conjunctive queries and denial constraints containing one database atom plus built-ins. Section 7 presents some conclusions and refers to related work. Proofs and other auxiliary, technical results can be found in Appendix 0.A.1.

2 Preliminaries

Consider a relational schema Σ=(𝒰,ℛ,ℬ,𝒜)Σ𝒰ℛℬ𝒜\Sigma=({\cal U},{\cal R},{\cal B},{\cal A})roman_Σ = ( caligraphic_U , caligraphic_R , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_A ), with domain 𝒰𝒰{\cal U}caligraphic_U that includes ℤ,ℤ\mathbb{Z},blackboard_Z ,111With simple denial constraints, numbers can be restricted to, e.g. ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N or {0,1}01\{0,1\}{ 0 , 1 }. ℛℛ{\cal R}caligraphic_R a set of database predicates, ℬℬ{\cal B}caligraphic_B a set of built-in predicates, and 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A a set of attributes. A database instance is a finite collection D𝐷Ditalic_D of database tuples, i.e. of ground atoms P⁢(c¯)𝑃¯𝑐P(\bar{c})italic_P ( over¯ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG ), with P∈ℛ𝑃ℛP\in{\cal R}italic_P ∈ caligraphic_R and c¯¯𝑐\bar{c}over¯ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG a tuple of constants in 𝒰𝒰\cal Ucaligraphic_U. There is a set ℱ⊆𝒜ℱ𝒜{\cal F}\subseteq{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_F ⊆ caligraphic_A of all the fixable attributes, those that take values in ℤℤ\mathbb{Z}blackboard_Z and are allowed to be fixed. Attributes outside ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F are called rigid. ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F need not contain all the numerical attributes, that is we may also have rigid numerical attributes.

We also have a set 𝒦𝒦{\cal K}caligraphic_K of key constraints expressing that relations R∈ℛ𝑅ℛR\in{\cal R}italic_R ∈ caligraphic_R have a primary key KRsubscript𝐾𝑅K_{\!R}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, KR⊆(𝒜∖ℱ)subscript𝐾𝑅𝒜ℱK_{\!R}\subseteq({\mathcal{A}}\smallsetminus{\cal F})italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ ( caligraphic_A ∖ caligraphic_F ). Later on (c.f. Definition 2), we will assume that 𝒦𝒦{\cal K}caligraphic_K is satisfied both by the initial instance D𝐷Ditalic_D, denoted D⊧𝒦models𝐷𝒦D\models{\cal K}italic_D ⊧ caligraphic_K, and its fixes. Since ℱ∩KR=∅ℱsubscript𝐾𝑅{\cal F}\cap K_{\!R}=\emptysetcaligraphic_F ∩ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∅, values in key attributes cannot be changed in a fixing process; so the constraints in 𝒦𝒦\cal Kcaligraphic_K are hard. In addition, there may be a separate set IC of flexible ICs that may be violated, and it is the job of a fix to restore consistency wrt them (while still satisfying 𝒦𝒦\cal Kcaligraphic_K).

A linear denial constraint [18] has the form  ∀x¯⁢¬⁡(A1∧…∧Am)for-all¯𝑥subscript𝐴1…subscript𝐴𝑚\forall\bar{x}\neg(A_{1}\wedge\ldots\wedge A_{m})∀ over¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ¬ ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∧ … ∧ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where the Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are database atoms (i.e. with predicate in ℛℛ{\cal R}caligraphic_R), or built-in atoms of the form x⁢θ⁢c𝑥𝜃𝑐x\theta citalic_x italic_θ italic_c, where x𝑥xitalic_x is a variable, c𝑐citalic_c is a constant and θ∈{=,\theta\in\{=,italic_θ ∈ { = , ≠\neq≠, <<<, >,>,> , ≤,\leq,≤ , ≥}\geq\}≥ }, or x=y𝑥𝑦x=yitalic_x = italic_y. If x≠y𝑥𝑦x\neq yitalic_x ≠ italic_y is allowed, we call them extended linear denials.

Example 2

The following are linear denials (we replace ∧\wedge∧ by a comma): (a) No customer is younger than 21:  ∀𝐼𝑑,for-all𝐼𝑑\forall{\it Id},∀ italic_Id , 𝐴𝑔𝑒,𝐼𝑛𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑒,𝑆𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑢𝑠¬(𝐶𝑢𝑠𝑡𝑜𝑚𝑒𝑟(𝐼𝑑,𝐴𝑔𝑒,{\it Age,Income,Status}\neg({\it Customer(Id,Age},italic_Age , italic_Income , italic_Status ¬ ( italic_Customer ( italic_Id , italic_Age , 𝐼𝑛𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑒,𝐼𝑛𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑒{\it Income},italic_Income , 𝑆𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑢𝑠),𝐴𝑔𝑒<21){\it Status}),{\it Age}<21)italic_Status ) , italic_Age < 21 ). (b) No customer with income less than 60000 has “silver” status: ∀𝐼𝑑,𝐴𝑔𝑒,for-all𝐼𝑑𝐴𝑔𝑒\forall{\it Id,Age,}∀ italic_Id , italic_Age , 𝐼𝑛𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑒,𝑆𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑢𝑠¬(𝐶𝑢𝑠𝑡𝑜𝑚𝑒𝑟(𝐼𝑑,𝐴𝑔𝑒,{\it Income,Status}\neg({\it Customer(Id,Age},italic_Income , italic_Status ¬ ( italic_Customer ( italic_Id , italic_Age , 𝐼𝑛𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑒,𝑆𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑢𝑠),{\it Income,Status)},italic_Income , italic_Status ) , 𝐼𝑛𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑒𝐼𝑛𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑒{\it Income}italic_Income <60000,𝑆𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑢𝑠=𝑠𝑖𝑙𝑣𝑒𝑟)<60000,{\it Status}={\it silver})< 60000 , italic_Status = italic_silver ). (c) The constraints in Example 1, e.g.

We consider aggregation constraints (ACs) [23] and aggregate queries with sum, count, average. Filtering ACs impose conditions on the tuples over which aggregation is applied, e.g. 𝑠𝑢𝑚(A1:A2=3)> 5{\it sum}(A_{1}\!:A_{2}=3)\ >\ 5italic_sum ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3 ) > 5 is a sum over A1subscript𝐴1A_{1}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of tuples with A2=3subscript𝐴23A_{2}=3italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3. Multi-attribute ACs allow arithmetical combinations of attributes as arguments for 𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑠𝑢𝑚{\it sum}italic_sum, e.g. s⁢u⁢m⁢(A1+A2)>5𝑠𝑢𝑚subscript𝐴1subscript𝐴25sum(A_{1}+A_{2})>5italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > 5 and s⁢u⁢m⁢(A1×A2)>100𝑠𝑢𝑚subscript𝐴1subscript𝐴2100sum(A_{1}\times A_{2})>100italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > 100. If an AC has attributes from more than one relation, it is multi-relation, e.g. s⁢u⁢mR1⁢(A1)=s⁢u⁢mR2⁢(A1)𝑠𝑢subscript𝑚subscript𝑅1subscript𝐴1𝑠𝑢subscript𝑚subscript𝑅2subscript𝐴1sum_{R_{1}}(A_{1})=sum_{R_{2}}(A_{1})italic_s italic_u italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_s italic_u italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), otherwise it is single-relation.

An aggregate conjunctive query has the form q(x1,…xm;𝑎𝑔𝑔(z))←B(x1,q(x_{1},\ldots x_{m};~{}{\it agg}(z))\leftarrow B(x_{1},italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_agg ( italic_z ) ) ← italic_B ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , …,…\ldots,… , xm,subscript𝑥𝑚x_{m},italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , z,y1,…,𝑧subscript𝑦1…z,y_{1},\ldots,italic_z , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , yn)y_{n})italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where 𝑎𝑔𝑔𝑎𝑔𝑔{\it agg}italic_agg is an aggregation function and its non-aggregate matrix (NAM) given by q′(x1,…xm)←B(x1,…,xm,q^{\prime}(x_{1},\ldots x_{m})\leftarrow B(x_{1},\ldots,x_{m},italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ← italic_B ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , z𝑧zitalic_z, y1,…,subscript𝑦1…y_{1},\ldots,italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , yn)y_{n})italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a usual first-order (FO) conjunctive query with built-in atoms, such that the aggregation attribute z𝑧zitalic_z does not appear among the xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here we use the set semantics. An aggregate conjunctive query is cyclic (acyclic) if its NAM is cyclic (acyclic) [2].

Example 3

q⁢(x,y,s⁢u⁢m⁢(z))←R⁢(x,y),Q⁢(y,z,w),←𝑞𝑥𝑦𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑧𝑅𝑥𝑦𝑄𝑦𝑧𝑤q(x,y,sum(z))\leftarrow R(x,y),Q(y,z,w),italic_q ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) ) ← italic_R ( italic_x , italic_y ) , italic_Q ( italic_y , italic_z , italic_w ) , w≠3𝑤3w\neq 3italic_w ≠ 3 is an aggregate conjunctive query, with aggregation attribute z𝑧zitalic_z. Each answer (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y)( italic_x , italic_y ) to its NAM, i.e. to q⁢(x,y)←R⁢(x,y),Q⁢(y,z,w),w≠3formulae-sequence←𝑞𝑥𝑦𝑅𝑥𝑦𝑄𝑦𝑧𝑤𝑤3q(x,y)\leftarrow R(x,y),Q(y,z,w),w\neq 3italic_q ( italic_x , italic_y ) ← italic_R ( italic_x , italic_y ) , italic_Q ( italic_y , italic_z , italic_w ) , italic_w ≠ 3, is expanded to (x,y,s⁢u⁢m⁢(z))𝑥𝑦𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑧(x,y,sum(z))( italic_x , italic_y , italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) ) as an answer to the aggregate query.  s⁢u⁢m⁢(z)𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑧sum(z)italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) is the sum of all the values for z𝑧zitalic_z having a w𝑤witalic_w, such that (x,y,z,w)𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑤(x,y,z,w)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z , italic_w ) makes R⁢(x,y),Q⁢(y,z,w),w≠3𝑅𝑥𝑦𝑄𝑦𝑧𝑤𝑤3R(x,y),Q(y,z,w),w\neq 3italic_R ( italic_x , italic_y ) , italic_Q ( italic_y , italic_z , italic_w ) , italic_w ≠ 3 true. In the database instance D={R(1,2),D=\{R(1,2),italic_D = { italic_R ( 1 , 2 ) , R⁢(2,3),𝑅23R(2,3),italic_R ( 2 , 3 ) , Q⁢(2,5,9),Q⁢(2,6,7),𝑄259𝑄267Q(2,5,9),Q(2,6,7),italic_Q ( 2 , 5 , 9 ) , italic_Q ( 2 , 6 , 7 ) , Q⁢(3,1,1),Q⁢(3,1,5),𝑄311𝑄315Q(3,1,1),Q(3,1,5),italic_Q ( 3 , 1 , 1 ) , italic_Q ( 3 , 1 , 5 ) , Q(3,8,3)}Q(3,8,3)\}italic_Q ( 3 , 8 , 3 ) } the answer set for the aggregate query is {(1,2,5+6),(2,3,1+1)}12562311\{(1,2,5+6),(2,3,1+1)\}{ ( 1 , 2 , 5 + 6 ) , ( 2 , 3 , 1 + 1 ) }. □□\Box□

An aggregate comparison query is a sentence of the form q⁢(𝑎𝑔𝑔⁢(z)),𝑎𝑔𝑔⁢(z)⁢θ⁢k𝑞𝑎𝑔𝑔𝑧𝑎𝑔𝑔𝑧𝜃𝑘q({\it agg}(z)),{\it agg}(z)\theta kitalic_q ( italic_agg ( italic_z ) ) , italic_agg ( italic_z ) italic_θ italic_k, where q⁢(𝑎𝑔𝑔⁢(z))𝑞𝑎𝑔𝑔𝑧q({\it agg(z)})italic_q ( italic_agg ( italic_z ) ) is the head of a scalar aggregate conjunctive query (with no free variables), θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ is a comparison operator, and k𝑘kitalic_k is an integer number. For example, the following is an aggregate comparison query asking whether the aggregated value obtained via q⁢(s⁢u⁢m⁢(z))𝑞𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑧q(sum(z))italic_q ( italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) ) is bigger than 5: Q:q⁢(s⁢u⁢m⁢(z)),s⁢u⁢m⁢(z)>5:𝑄𝑞𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑧𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑧5Q\!:q(sum(z)),sum(z)>5italic_Q : italic_q ( italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) ) , italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) > 5, with q⁢(s⁢u⁢m⁢(z))←R⁢(x,y),Q⁢(y,z,w),w≠3formulae-sequence←𝑞𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑧𝑅𝑥𝑦𝑄𝑦𝑧𝑤𝑤3q(sum(z))\leftarrow R(x,y),Q(y,z,w),w\neq 3italic_q ( italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) ) ← italic_R ( italic_x , italic_y ) , italic_Q ( italic_y , italic_z , italic_w ) , italic_w ≠ 3.

3 Least Squares Fixes

When we update numerical values to restore consistency, it is desirable to make the smallest overall variation of the original values, while considering the relative relevance or specific scale of each of the fixable attributes. Since the original instance and a fix will share the same key values (c.f. Definition 2), we can use them to compute variations in the numerical values. For a tuple k¯¯𝑘\bar{k}over¯ start_ARG italic_k end_ARG of values for the key KRsubscript𝐾𝑅K_{\!R}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of relation R𝑅Ritalic_R in an instance D𝐷Ditalic_D, t¯⁢(k¯,R,D)¯𝑡¯𝑘𝑅𝐷\bar{t}(\bar{k},R,D)over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ( over¯ start_ARG italic_k end_ARG , italic_R , italic_D ) denotes the unique tuple t¯¯𝑡\bar{t}over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG in relation R𝑅Ritalic_R in instance D𝐷Ditalic_D whose key value is k¯¯𝑘\bar{k}over¯ start_ARG italic_k end_ARG. To each attribute A∈ℱ𝐴ℱA\in{\cal F}italic_A ∈ caligraphic_F a fixed numerical weight αAsubscript𝛼𝐴\alpha_{\!{}_{A}}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is assigned.

Definition 1

For instances D𝐷{\it D}italic_D and D′superscript𝐷normal-′{\it D}^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over schema Σnormal-Σ\Sigmaroman_Σ with the same set 𝑣𝑎𝑙⁢(KR)𝑣𝑎𝑙subscript𝐾𝑅{\it val}(K_{\!R})italic_val ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of tuples of key values for each relation R∈ℛ𝑅ℛR\in{\cal R}italic_R ∈ caligraphic_R, their square distance is
             Δα¯⁢(D,D′)=∑k¯∈𝑣𝑎𝑙⁢(KR)R∈ℛ,A∈ℱαA⁢(πA⁢(t¯⁢(k¯,R,D))−πA⁢(t¯⁢(k¯,R,D′)))2,subscriptnormal-Δnormal-¯𝛼𝐷superscript𝐷normal-′subscriptsuperscriptnormal-¯𝑘𝑣𝑎𝑙subscript𝐾𝑅formulae-sequence𝑅ℛ𝐴ℱsubscript𝛼𝐴superscriptsubscript𝜋𝐴normal-¯𝑡normal-¯𝑘𝑅𝐷subscript𝜋𝐴normal-¯𝑡normal-¯𝑘𝑅superscript𝐷normal-′2\Delta_{\bar{\alpha}}({\it D},{\it D}^{\prime})=\sum_{\stackrel{{\scriptstyle R\in{\cal R},A\in{\cal F}}}{{\bar{k}\in{\it val}(K_{\!R})}}}\alpha_{\!{}_{A}}(\pi_{\!{}_{A}}(\bar{t}(\bar{k},R,D))-\pi_{\!{}_{A}}(\bar{t}(\bar{k},R,D^{\prime})))^{2},roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG over¯ start_ARG italic_k end_ARG ∈ italic_val ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_R ∈ caligraphic_R , italic_A ∈ caligraphic_F end_ARG end_RELOP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ( over¯ start_ARG italic_k end_ARG , italic_R , italic_D ) ) - italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ( over¯ start_ARG italic_k end_ARG , italic_R , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,
where πAsubscript𝜋𝐴\pi_{\!{}_{A}}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the projection on attribute A𝐴Aitalic_A and α¯=(αA)A∈ℱnormal-¯𝛼subscriptsubscript𝛼𝐴𝐴ℱ\bar{\alpha}=(\alpha_{\!{}_{A}})_{A\in{\cal F}}over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG = ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A ∈ caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. □normal-□\Box□

Definition 2

For an instance D𝐷Ditalic_D, a set of fixable attributes ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F, a set of key dependencies 𝒦𝒦{\cal K}caligraphic_K, such that D⊧𝒦models𝐷𝒦D\models{\cal K}italic_D ⊧ caligraphic_K, and a set of flexible ICs IC:  A fix for D𝐷Ditalic_D wrt IC is an instance D′superscript𝐷normal-′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that: (a) D′superscript𝐷normal-′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has the same schema and domain as D𝐷Ditalic_D; (b) D′superscript𝐷normal-′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has the same values as D𝐷Ditalic_D in the attributes in 𝒜∖ℱ𝒜ℱ{\mathcal{A}}\smallsetminus{\cal F}caligraphic_A ∖ caligraphic_F; (c) D′⊧𝒦modelssuperscript𝐷normal-′𝒦D^{\prime}\models{\cal K}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊧ caligraphic_K; and (d) D′⊧𝐼𝐶modelssuperscript𝐷normal-′𝐼𝐶D^{\prime}\models{\textit{IC}}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊧ IC.  A least squares fix (LS-fix) for D𝐷Ditalic_D is a fix D′superscript𝐷normal-′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that minimizes the square distance Δα¯⁢(D,D′)subscriptnormal-Δnormal-¯𝛼𝐷superscript𝐷normal-′\Delta_{\bar{\alpha}}(D,D^{\prime})roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) over all the instances that satisfy (a) - (d). □normal-□\Box□

In general we are interested in LS-fixes, but (non-necessarily minimal) fixes will be useful auxiliary instances.

Example 4

(example 1 cont.) ℛ=ℛabsent{\cal R}=caligraphic_R = {𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐},𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐\{{\it Traffic}\},{ italic_Traffic } , 𝒜={Time,{\mathcal{A}}=\{Time,caligraphic_A = { italic_T italic_i italic_m italic_e , L⁢i⁢n⁢k,𝐿𝑖𝑛𝑘Link,italic_L italic_i italic_n italic_k , T⁢y⁢p⁢e,𝑇𝑦𝑝𝑒Type,italic_T italic_y italic_p italic_e , Flow}Flow\}italic_F italic_l italic_o italic_w }, K𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐={T⁢i⁢m⁢e,L⁢i⁢n⁢k}subscript𝐾𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐𝑇𝑖𝑚𝑒𝐿𝑖𝑛𝑘K_{\!{\it Traffic}}=\{Time,Link\}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Traffic end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_T italic_i italic_m italic_e , italic_L italic_i italic_n italic_k }, ℱ=ℱabsent{\cal F}=caligraphic_F = {Type,\{Type,{ italic_T italic_y italic_p italic_e , Flow}Flow\}italic_F italic_l italic_o italic_w }, with weights α¯=(10−5,1)¯𝛼superscript1051{\bar{\alpha}}=(10^{-5},1)over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG = ( 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 1 ), resp. For original instance D𝐷Ditalic_D, 𝑣𝑎𝑙⁢(K𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐)𝑣𝑎𝑙subscript𝐾𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐{\it val}(K_{\!{\it Traffic}})italic_val ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Traffic end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ={(1.1,a),(1.1,b),(1.3,b)},absent1.1𝑎1.1𝑏1.3𝑏=\{(1.1,a),(1.1,b),(1.3,b)\},= { ( 1.1 , italic_a ) , ( 1.1 , italic_b ) , ( 1.3 , italic_b ) } , t¯((1.1,a),\bar{t}((1.1,a),over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ( ( 1.1 , italic_a ) , 𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐,D)=(1.1,a,0,1100){\it Traffic},D)=(1.1,a,0,1100)italic_Traffic , italic_D ) = ( 1.1 , italic_a , 0 , 1100 ), etc. Fixes are D1={(1.1,a,0,1000),D_{1}=\{(1.1,a,0,1000),italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { ( 1.1 , italic_a , 0 , 1000 ) , (1.1,b,1,900),1.1𝑏1900(1.1,b,1,900),( 1.1 , italic_b , 1 , 900 ) , (1.3,b,1,850)}(1.3,b,1,850)\}( 1.3 , italic_b , 1 , 850 ) } and D2={(1.1,a,1,1100),D_{2}=\{(1.1,a,1,1100),italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { ( 1.1 , italic_a , 1 , 1100 ) , (1.1,b,1,900),1.1𝑏1900(1.1,b,1,900),( 1.1 , italic_b , 1 , 900 ) , (1.3,b,1,850)}(1.3,b,1,850)\}( 1.3 , italic_b , 1 , 850 ) }, with distances  Δα¯⁢(D,D1)subscriptΔ¯𝛼𝐷subscript𝐷1\Delta_{\bar{\alpha}}(D,D_{1})roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =1002×10−5=10−1absentsuperscript1002superscript105superscript101=100^{2}\times 10^{-5}=10^{-1}= 100 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and  Δα¯⁢(D,D2)=12×1subscriptΔ¯𝛼𝐷subscript𝐷2superscript121\Delta_{\bar{\alpha}}(D,D_{2})=1^{2}\times 1roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × 1, resp. Therefore, D1subscript𝐷1D_{1}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the only LS-fix. □□\Box□

The coefficients αAsubscript𝛼𝐴\alpha_{\!{}_{A}}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be chosen in many different ways depending on factors like relative relevance of attributes, actual distribution of data, measurement scales, etc. In the rest of this paper we will assume, for simplification, that αA=1subscript𝛼𝐴1\alpha_{\!{}_{A}}=1italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for all A∈ℱ𝐴ℱA\in{\cal F}italic_A ∈ caligraphic_F and Δα¯⁢(D,D′)subscriptΔ¯𝛼𝐷superscript𝐷′\Delta_{\bar{\alpha}}({\it D},{\it D}^{\prime})roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) will be simply denoted by Δ⁢(D,D′)Δ𝐷superscript𝐷′\Delta({\it D},{\it D}^{\prime})roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Example 5

The database D𝐷Ditalic_D has relations 𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡(𝐼𝐷,{\it Client(ID,}italic_Client ( italic_ID , A,M){\it A,M)}italic_A , italic_M ), with key 𝐼𝐷𝐼𝐷{\it ID}italic_ID, attributes A𝐴Aitalic_A for age and M𝑀Mitalic_M for amount of money; and 𝐵𝑢𝑦⁢(𝐼𝐷,I,P)𝐵𝑢𝑦𝐼𝐷𝐼𝑃{\it Buy(ID,I,P)}italic_Buy ( italic_ID , italic_I , italic_P ), with key {𝐼𝐷,I}𝐼𝐷𝐼\{{\it ID},I\}{ italic_ID , italic_I }, I𝐼Iitalic_I for items, and P𝑃Pitalic_P for prices. We have denials  𝐼𝐶1:∀𝐼𝐷,P,A,M¬({\textit{IC}}_{1}\!:~{}\forall{\it ID},P,A,M\neg(IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : ∀ italic_ID , italic_P , italic_A , italic_M ¬ ( 𝐵𝑢𝑦⁢(𝐼𝐷,I,P),𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡⁢(𝐼𝐷,A,M),A<18,𝐵𝑢𝑦𝐼𝐷𝐼𝑃𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡𝐼𝐷𝐴𝑀𝐴18{\it Buy(ID},I,P),{\it Client(ID},A,M),A<18,italic_Buy ( italic_ID , italic_I , italic_P ) , italic_Client ( italic_ID , italic_A , italic_M ) , italic_A < 18 , P>25)P>25)italic_P > 25 )  and  𝐼𝐶2:∀𝐼𝐷,A,M¬({\textit{IC}}_{2}\!:\forall{\it ID},A,M\neg(IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : ∀ italic_ID , italic_A , italic_M ¬ ( 𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡({\it Client}(italic_Client ( 𝐼𝐷,A,M),A<18,{\it ID},A,M),A<18,italic_ID , italic_A , italic_M ) , italic_A < 18 , M>50)M>50)italic_M > 50 ), requiring that people younger than 18 can-

I⁢C1𝐼subscript𝐶1IC_{1}italic_I italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is violated by {t1subscript𝑡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,t4subscript𝑡4t_{4}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT} and {t1subscript𝑡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,t5subscript𝑡5t_{5}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT}; and 𝐼𝐶2subscript𝐼𝐶2{\textit{IC}}_{2}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by {t1subscript𝑡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT} and {t2subscript𝑡2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT}. We have two LS-fixes (the modified version of tuple t1subscript𝑡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is t1′superscriptsubscript𝑡1′t_{1}^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, etc.), with distances Δ⁢(D,D′)=Δ𝐷superscript𝐷′absent\Delta(D,D^{\prime})=roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) =

1 18 52 t1subscript𝑡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT′′′′{}^{\prime\prime}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT

3 60 900 t3subscript𝑡3t_{3}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
 Buy”   ID  I  P
1 CD 27 t4subscript𝑡4t_{4}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
1 DVD 26 t5subscript𝑡5t_{5}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
3 DVD 40 t6subscript𝑡6t_{6}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

22+12+22+12=10superscript22superscript12superscript22superscript12102^{2}+1^{2}+2^{2}+1^{2}=102 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 10, and Δ⁢(D,D′′)=32+12=10Δ𝐷superscript𝐷′′superscript32superscript1210\Delta(D,D^{\prime\prime})=3^{2}+1^{2}=10roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 10. We can see that a global fix may not be the result of applying “local” minimal fixes to tuples. □□\Box□

The built-in atoms in linear denials determine a solution space for fixes as an intersection of semi-spaces, and LS-fixes can be found at its “borders” (c.f. previous example and Proposition A.0.A.1 in Appendix 0.A.1). It is easy to construct examples with an exponential number of fixes. For the kind of fixes and ICs we are considering, it is possible that no fix exists, in contrast to [3, 4], where, if the set of ICs is consistent as a set of logical sentences, a fix for a database always exist.

Example 6

R⁢(X,Y)𝑅𝑋𝑌R(X,Y)italic_R ( italic_X , italic_Y ) has key X𝑋Xitalic_X and fixable Y𝑌Yitalic_Y. 𝐼𝐶1={∀X1X2Y¬(R(X1,Y),{\textit{IC}}_{1}=\{\forall X_{1}X_{2}Y\neg(R(X_{1},Y),IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { ∀ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y ¬ ( italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y ) , R(X2,R(X_{2},italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , Y),X1=1,X2=2)Y),X_{1}\!=\!1,X_{2}\!=\!2)italic_Y ) , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 ), ​∀X1X2Y¬(R(X1,\forall X_{1}X_{2}Y\neg(R(X_{1},∀ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y ¬ ( italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , Y),Y),italic_Y ) , R(X2,Y),X1=1,X2=3)R(X_{2},Y),X_{1}\!=\!1,X_{2}\!=\!3)italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y ) , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3 ), ∀X1X2Y¬(\forall X_{1}X_{2}Y\neg(∀ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y ¬ ( R(X1,Y),R(X2,Y),X1=2,X2=3)R(X_{1},Y),R(X_{2},Y),\!X_{1}\!=\!2,\!X_{2}\!=\!3)italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y ) , italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y ) , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3 ), ​∀X⁢Y⁢¬⁡(R⁢(X,Y),Y>3)for-all𝑋𝑌𝑅𝑋𝑌𝑌3\forall XY\neg(R(X,Y),Y\!\!>\!3)∀ italic_X italic_Y ¬ ( italic_R ( italic_X , italic_Y ) , italic_Y > 3 ), ​∀XY¬(\forall XY\neg(∀ italic_X italic_Y ¬ ( R(X,Y),Y<2)}R(X,Y),Y\!<\!2)\}italic_R ( italic_X , italic_Y ) , italic_Y < 2 ) } is consistent. The first three ICs force Y𝑌Yitalic_Y to be different in every tuple. The last two ICs require 2≤Y≤32𝑌32\leq Y\leq 32 ≤ italic_Y ≤ 3. The inconsistent database R={(1,−1),(2,1),R=\{(1,-1),(2,1),italic_R = { ( 1 , - 1 ) , ( 2 , 1 ) , (3,5)}(3,5)\}( 3 , 5 ) } has no fix. Now, for 𝐼𝐶2subscript𝐼𝐶2{\textit{IC}}_{2}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with ∀X,Y¬(R(X,Y),\forall X,Y\neg(R(X,Y),∀ italic_X , italic_Y ¬ ( italic_R ( italic_X , italic_Y ) , Y>1)Y>1)italic_Y > 1 ) and 𝑠𝑢𝑚⁢(Y)=10𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑌10{\it sum}(Y)=10italic_sum ( italic_Y ) = 10, any database with less than 10 tuples has no fixes. □□\Box□

Proposition 1

If D𝐷Ditalic_D has a fix wrt IC, then it also has an LS-fix wrt IC. □normal-□\Box□

4 Decidability and Complexity

In applications where fixes are based on changes of numerical values, computing concrete fixes is a relevant problem. In databases containing census forms, correcting the latter before doing statistical processing is a common problem [11]. In databases with experimental samples, we can fix certain erroneous quantities as specified by linear ICs. In these cases, the fixes are relevant objects to compute explicitly, which contrasts with CQA [3], where the main motivation for introducing repairs is to formally characterize the notion of a consistent answer to a query as an answer that remains under all possible repairs. In consequence, we now consider some decision problems related to existence and verification of LS-fixes, and to CQA under different semantics.

Definition 3

For an instance D𝐷Ditalic_D and a set IC of ICs:
(a) 𝐹𝑖𝑥⁢(D,𝐼𝐶):=assign𝐹𝑖𝑥𝐷𝐼𝐶absent{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}}):=italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) := {D′|D′ is an \{D^{\prime}~{}|~{}D^{\prime}~{}\mbox{ is an }{ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an LS-fix of ⁢DLS-fix of 𝐷\mbox{LS-fix of }{\it D}LS-fix of italic_D wrt 𝐼𝐶}\mbox{wrt }{\textit{IC}}\}italic_wrt italic_IC }, the fix checking problem.
(b) 𝐹𝑖𝑥(𝐼𝐶):={(D,D′){\it Fix}({\textit{IC}}):=\{(D,D^{\prime})italic_Fix ( IC ) := { ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) |D′∈𝐹𝑖𝑥(D,𝐼𝐶)}|~{}D^{\prime}\in{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})\}| italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) }.
(c) 𝑁𝐸(𝐼𝐶):={D|{\it NE}({\textit{IC}}):=\{D~{}|italic_NE ( IC ) := { italic_D | 𝐹𝑖𝑥⁢(D,𝐼𝐶)𝐹𝑖𝑥𝐷𝐼𝐶{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) ≠∅}\neq\emptyset\}≠ ∅ }, for non-empty set of fixes, i.e. the problem of checking existence of LS-fixes.
(d) 𝑁𝐸:={(D,𝐼𝐶)|𝐹𝑖𝑥⁢(D,𝐼𝐶)≠∅}assign𝑁𝐸conditional-set𝐷𝐼𝐶𝐹𝑖𝑥𝐷𝐼𝐶{\it NE}:=\{(D,{\textit{IC}})~{}|~{}{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})\neq\emptyset\}italic_NE := { ( italic_D , IC ) | italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) ≠ ∅ }.
(e) 𝐷𝐹𝑃⁢(𝐼𝐶):={(D,k)| there is ⁢D′∈F⁢i⁢x⁢(D,𝐼𝐶)⁢ with ⁢Δ⁢(D,D′)≤k}assign𝐷𝐹𝑃𝐼𝐶conditional-set𝐷𝑘 there is superscript𝐷normal-′𝐹𝑖𝑥𝐷𝐼𝐶 with normal-Δ𝐷superscript𝐷normal-′𝑘{\it DFP}({\textit{IC}})\!:=\!\!\{(D,k)|\mbox{ there is }D^{\prime}\in Fix(D,{\textit{IC}})\mbox{ with }\Delta(D,D^{\prime})\leq k\}italic_DFP ( IC ) := { ( italic_D , italic_k ) | there is italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_F italic_i italic_x ( italic_D , IC ) with roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_k }, the database fix problem, i.e. the problem of checking existence of LS-fixes within a given positive distance k𝑘kitalic_k.
(f) 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃⁢(𝐼𝐶)𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐼𝐶{\it DFOP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFOP ( IC ) is the optimization problem of finding the minimum distance from an LS-fix wrt IC to a given input instance. □normal-□\Box□

Definition 4

Let D𝐷Ditalic_D be a database, IC a set ICs, and Q𝑄Qitalic_Q a conjunctive query222Whenever we say just “conjunctive query” we understand it is a non aggregate query..
(a) A ground tuple t¯normal-¯𝑡\bar{t}over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG is a consistent answer to Q⁢(x¯)𝑄normal-¯𝑥Q(\bar{x})italic_Q ( over¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) under the:  (a1) skeptical semantics if for every D′∈𝐹𝑖𝑥⁢(D,𝐼𝐶)superscript𝐷normal-′𝐹𝑖𝑥𝐷𝐼𝐶D^{\prime}\in{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ), D′⊧Q⁢(t¯)modelssuperscript𝐷normal-′𝑄normal-¯𝑡D^{\prime}\models Q(\bar{t})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊧ italic_Q ( over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ).  (a2) brave semantics if there exists D′∈𝐹𝑖𝑥⁢(D,𝐼𝐶)superscript𝐷normal-′𝐹𝑖𝑥𝐷𝐼𝐶D^{\prime}\in{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) with D′⊧Q⁢(t¯)modelssuperscript𝐷normal-′𝑄normal-¯𝑡D^{\prime}\models Q(\bar{t})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊧ italic_Q ( over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ).  (a3) majority semantics if |{D′|D′∈𝐹𝑖𝑥(D,𝐼𝐶)|\{D^{\prime}~{}|~{}D^{\prime}\in{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})| { italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) and D′⊧modelssuperscript𝐷normal-′absentD^{\prime}\modelsitalic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊧ Q(t¯)}|Q(\bar{t})\}|italic_Q ( over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ) } | >>> |{D′|D′∈|\{D^{\prime}~{}|~{}D^{\prime}\in| { italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ 𝐹𝑖𝑥⁢(D,𝐼𝐶)𝐹𝑖𝑥𝐷𝐼𝐶{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) and D′⊧̸Q(t¯)}|D^{\prime}\not\models Q(\bar{t})\}|italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊧̸ italic_Q ( over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ) } |.
(b) That t¯normal-¯𝑡\bar{t}over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG is a consistent answer to Q𝑄Qitalic_Q in D𝐷Ditalic_D under semantics 𝒮𝒮\cal Scaligraphic_S is denoted by D⊧𝒮Q⁢[t¯]subscriptmodels𝒮𝐷𝑄delimited-[]normal-¯𝑡D\models_{\cal S}Q[\bar{t}]italic_D ⊧ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q [ over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ]. If Q𝑄Qitalic_Q is ground and D⊧𝒮Qsubscriptmodels𝒮𝐷𝑄D\models_{\cal S}Qitalic_D ⊧ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q, we say that yes  is a consistent answer, meaning that Q𝑄Qitalic_Q is true in the fixes of D𝐷Ditalic_D according to semantics S𝑆Sitalic_S. 𝐶𝐴⁢(Q,D,𝐼𝐶,𝒮)𝐶𝐴𝑄𝐷𝐼𝐶𝒮{\it CA}(Q,D,{\textit{IC}},{\cal S})italic_CA ( italic_Q , italic_D , IC , caligraphic_S ) is the set of consistent answers to Q𝑄Qitalic_Q in D𝐷Ditalic_D wrt IC under semantics 𝒮𝒮{\cal S}caligraphic_S. For ground Q𝑄Qitalic_Q, if 𝐶𝐴⁢(Q,D,𝐼𝐶,𝒮)≠{𝑦𝑒𝑠}𝐶𝐴𝑄𝐷𝐼𝐶𝒮𝑦𝑒𝑠{\it CA}(Q,D,{\textit{IC}},{\cal S})\neq\{{\it yes}\}italic_CA ( italic_Q , italic_D , IC , caligraphic_S ) ≠ { italic_yes }, 𝐶𝐴⁢(Q,D,𝐼𝐶,𝒮):={𝑛𝑜}assign𝐶𝐴𝑄𝐷𝐼𝐶𝒮𝑛𝑜{\it CA}(Q,D,{\textit{IC}},{\cal S}):=\{{\it no}\}italic_CA ( italic_Q , italic_D , IC , caligraphic_S ) := { italic_no }.
(c) 𝐶𝑄𝐴⁢(Q,𝐼𝐶,𝒮):={(D,t¯)|t¯∈𝐶𝐴⁢(Q,D,𝐼𝐶,𝒮)}assign𝐶𝑄𝐴𝑄𝐼𝐶𝒮conditional-set𝐷normal-¯𝑡normal-¯𝑡𝐶𝐴𝑄𝐷𝐼𝐶𝒮{\it CQA}(Q,{\textit{IC}},{\cal S}):=\{(D,\bar{t})~{}|~{}\bar{t}\in{\it CA}(Q,D,{\textit{IC}},{\cal S})\}italic_CQA ( italic_Q , IC , caligraphic_S ) := { ( italic_D , over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ) | over¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ∈ italic_CA ( italic_Q , italic_D , IC , caligraphic_S ) } is the decision problem of consistent query answering, of checking consistent answers. □normal-□\Box□

Proposition 2

𝑁𝐸⁢(𝐼𝐶)𝑁𝐸𝐼𝐶{\it NE}({{\textit{IC}}})italic_NE ( IC ) can be reduced in polynomial time to the complements of 𝐶𝑄𝐴(𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒,𝐼𝐶,{\it CQA}({\it False},{\textit{IC}},italic_CQA ( italic_False , IC , 𝑆𝑘𝑒𝑝𝑡𝑖𝑐𝑎𝑙){\it Skeptical})italic_Skeptical ) and 𝐶𝑄𝐴⁢(𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒,𝐼𝐶,𝑀𝑎𝑗𝑜𝑟𝑖𝑡𝑦)𝐶𝑄𝐴𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒𝐼𝐶𝑀𝑎𝑗𝑜𝑟𝑖𝑡𝑦{\it CQA}({\it True},{\textit{IC}},{\it Majority})italic_CQA ( italic_True , IC , italic_Majority ), where 𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒,𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒{\it False},{\it True}italic_False , italic_True are ground queries that are always false, resp. true. □normal-□\Box□

In Proposition 2, it suffices for queries 𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒,𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒{\it False},{\it True}italic_False , italic_True to be false, resp. true, in all instances that share the key values with the input database. Then, they can be represented by ∃Y⁢R⁢(c¯,Y)𝑌𝑅¯𝑐𝑌\exists YR(\bar{c},Y)∃ italic_Y italic_R ( over¯ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG , italic_Y ), where c¯¯𝑐\bar{c}over¯ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG are not (for False), or are (for True) key values in the original instance.

Theorem 4.1

Under extended linear denials and complex, filtering, multi-attri-bute, single-relation, aggregation constraints, the problems 𝑁𝐸𝑁𝐸{\it NE}italic_NE of existence of LS-fixes, and 𝐶𝑄𝐴𝐶𝑄𝐴{\it CQA}italic_CQA under skeptical or majority semantics are undecidable. □normal-□\Box□

The result about 𝑁𝐸𝑁𝐸{\it NE}italic_NE can be proved by reduction from the undecidable Hilbert’s problem on solvability of diophantine equations. For CQA, apply Proposition 2. Here we have the original database and the set of ICs as input parameters. In the following we will be interested in data complexity, when only the input database varies and the set of ICs is fixed [2].

Theorem 4.2

For a fixed set IC  of linear denials: (a) Deciding if for an instance D𝐷Ditalic_D there is an instance D′superscript𝐷normal-′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (with the same key values as D𝐷Ditalic_D) that satisfies IC with Δ⁢(D,D′)≤knormal-Δ𝐷superscript𝐷normal-′𝑘\Delta(D,D^{\prime})\leq kroman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_k, with positive integer k𝑘kitalic_k that is part of the input, is in 𝑁𝑃𝑁𝑃{\it NP}italic_NP. (b) 𝐷𝐹𝑃⁢(𝐼𝐶)𝐷𝐹𝑃𝐼𝐶{\it DFP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFP ( IC ) is 𝑁𝑃𝑁𝑃{\it NP}italic_NP-complete. (c.f. Definition 3(e)) □normal-□\Box□

By Proposition 1, there is a fix for D𝐷Ditalic_D wrt IC at a distance ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k iff there is an LS-fix at a distance ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k. Part (b) of Theorem 4.2 follows from part (a) and a reduction of Vertex Cover to 𝐷𝐹𝑃⁢(𝐼𝐶0)𝐷𝐹𝑃subscript𝐼𝐶0{\it DFP}({\textit{IC}}_{0})italic_DFP ( IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), for a fixed set of denials 𝐼𝐶0subscript𝐼𝐶0{\textit{IC}}_{0}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By Theorem 4.2(a), if there is a fix at a distance ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k, the minimum distance to D𝐷Ditalic_D for a fix can be found by binary search in l⁢o⁢g⁢(k)𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑘log(k)italic_l italic_o italic_g ( italic_k ) steps. Actually, if an LS-fix exists, its square distance to D𝐷Ditalic_D is polynomially bounded by the size of D𝐷Ditalic_D (c.f. proof of Theorem 4.3). Since D𝐷Ditalic_D and a fix have the same number of tuples, only the size of their values in a fix matter, and they are constrained by a fixed set of linear denials and the condition of minimality.

Theorem 4.3

For a fixed set IC of extended linear denials: (a) The problem 𝑁𝐸⁢(𝐼𝐶)𝑁𝐸𝐼𝐶{\it NE}({\textit{IC}})italic_NE ( IC ) of deciding if an instance has an LS-fix wrt IC  is 𝑁𝑃𝑁𝑃{\it NP}italic_NP-complete, and (b) 𝐶𝑄𝐴𝐶𝑄𝐴{\it CQA}italic_CQA under the skeptical and the majority semantics is 𝑐𝑜𝑁𝑃𝑐𝑜𝑁𝑃{\it coNP}italic_coNP-hard. □normal-□\Box□

For hardness in (a), (b) in Theorem 4.3, linear denials are good enough. Membership in (a) can be obtained for any fixed finite set of extended denials. Part (b) follows from part (a). The latter uses a reduction from 3-Colorability.

Theorem 4.4

For a fixed set IC of extended linear denials: (a) The problem 𝐹𝑖𝑥⁢(𝐼𝐶)𝐹𝑖𝑥𝐼𝐶{\it Fix}({\textit{IC}})italic_Fix ( IC ) of checking if an instance is an LS-fix is 𝑐𝑜𝑁𝑃𝑐𝑜𝑁𝑃{\it coNP}italic_coNP-complete, and (b) 𝐶𝑄𝐴𝐶𝑄𝐴{\it CQA}italic_CQA under skeptical semantics is in Π2Psubscriptsuperscriptnormal-Π𝑃2\Pi^{P}_{2}roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and, for ground atomic queries, Δ2Psuperscriptsubscriptnormal-Δ2𝑃\Delta_{2}^{P}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-hard. □normal-□\Box□

Part (a) uses 3SAT. Hardness in (b) is obtained by reduction from a Δ2PsubscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑃2\Delta^{P}_{2}roman_Δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-complete decision version of the problem of searching for the lexicographically Maximum 3-Satisfying Assignment (M3SA): Decide if the last variable takes value 1111 in it [17, Theo. 3.4]. Linear denials suffice. Now, by reduction from the Vertex Cover Problem, we obtain

Theorem 4.5

For aggregate comparison queries using 𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑠𝑢𝑚{\it sum}italic_sum, 𝐶𝑄𝐴𝐶𝑄𝐴{\it CQA}italic_CQA under linear denials and brave semantics is 𝑐𝑜𝑁𝑃𝑐𝑜𝑁𝑃{\it coNP}italic_coNP-hard. □normal-□\Box□

5 Approximation for the Database Fix Problem

We consider the problem of finding a good approximation for the general optimization problem 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃⁢(𝐼𝐶)𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐼𝐶{\it DFOP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFOP ( IC ).

Proposition 3

For a fixed set of linear denials IC, 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃⁢(𝐼𝐶)𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐼𝐶{\it DFOP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFOP ( IC ) is 𝑀𝐴𝑋𝑆𝑁𝑃𝑀𝐴𝑋𝑆𝑁𝑃{\it MAXSNP}italic_MAXSNP-hard. □normal-□\Box□

This result is obtained by establishing an L𝐿Litalic_L-reduction to 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃⁢(𝐼𝐶)𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐼𝐶{\it DFOP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFOP ( IC ) from the 𝑀𝐴𝑋𝑆𝑁𝑃𝑀𝐴𝑋𝑆𝑁𝑃{\it MAXSNP}italic_MAXSNP-complete [22, 21] B-Minimum Vertex Cover Problem, i.e. the vertex cover minimization problem for graphs of bounded degree [16, Chapter 10]. As an immediate consequence, we obtain that 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃⁢(𝐼𝐶)𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐼𝐶{\it DFOP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFOP ( IC ) cannot be uniformly approximated within arbitrarily small constant factors [21].

Corollary 1

Unless P=𝑁𝑃𝑃𝑁𝑃P\!=\!{\it NP}italic_P = italic_NP, there is no Polynomial Time Approximation Schema for 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP. □normal-□\Box□

This negative result does not preclude the possibility of finding an efficient algorithm for approximation within a constant factor for 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP. Actually, in the following we do this for a restricted but still useful class of denial constraints.

5.1 Local denials

Definition 5

A set of linear denials IC  is local if: (a) Attributes participating in equality atoms between attributes or in joins are all rigid; (b) There is a built-in atom with a fixable attribute in each element of IC; (c) No attribute A𝐴Aitalic_A appears in IC both in comparisons of the form A<c1𝐴subscript𝑐1A<c_{1}italic_A < italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and A>c2𝐴subscript𝑐2A>c_{2}italic_A > italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.333To check condition (c), x≤c,x≥c,x≠cformulae-sequence𝑥𝑐formulae-sequence𝑥𝑐𝑥𝑐x\leq c,~{}x\geq c,~{}x\neq citalic_x ≤ italic_c , italic_x ≥ italic_c , italic_x ≠ italic_c have to be expressed using <,><,>< , >, e.g. x≤c𝑥𝑐x\leq citalic_x ≤ italic_c by x<c+1𝑥𝑐1x<c+1italic_x < italic_c + 1. □normal-□\Box□

In Example 5, IC is local. In Example 6, 𝐼𝐶1subscript𝐼𝐶1{\textit{IC}}_{1}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not local. Local constraints have the property that by doing local fixes, no new inconsistencies are generated, and there is always an LS-fix wrt to them (c.f. Proposition A.11 in Appendix 0.A.1). Locality is a sufficient, but not necessary condition for existence of LS-fixes as can be seen from the database {P⁢(a,2)}𝑃𝑎2\{P(a,2)\}{ italic_P ( italic_a , 2 ) }, with the first attribute as a key and non-local denials ¬⁡(P⁢(x,y),y<3),¬⁡(P⁢(x,y),y>5)𝑃𝑥𝑦𝑦3𝑃𝑥𝑦𝑦5\neg(P(x,y),y<3),\neg(P(x,y),y>5)¬ ( italic_P ( italic_x , italic_y ) , italic_y < 3 ) , ¬ ( italic_P ( italic_x , italic_y ) , italic_y > 5 ), that has the LS-fix {P⁢(a,3)}𝑃𝑎3\{P(a,3)\}{ italic_P ( italic_a , 3 ) }.

Proposition 4

For the class of local denials, 𝐷𝐹𝑃𝐷𝐹𝑃{\it DFP}italic_DFP is 𝑁𝑃𝑁𝑃{\it NP}italic_NP-complete, and 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP is 𝑀𝐴𝑋𝑆𝑁𝑃𝑀𝐴𝑋𝑆𝑁𝑃{\it MAXSNP}italic_MAXSNP-hard. □normal-□\Box□

This proposition tells us that the problem of finding good approximations in the case of local denials is still relevant.

Definition 6

A set I𝐼Iitalic_I of database tuples from D𝐷Ditalic_D is a violation set for 𝑖𝑐∈𝐼𝐶𝑖𝑐𝐼𝐶{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic ∈ IC if I⊧̸𝑖𝑐not-models𝐼𝑖𝑐I\not\models{\it ic}italic_I ⊧̸ italic_ic, and for every I′⫋Isuperscript𝐼normal-′𝐼I^{\prime}\subsetneqq Iitalic_I start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⫋ italic_I, I′⊧𝑖𝑐modelssuperscript𝐼normal-′𝑖𝑐I^{\prime}\models{\it ic}italic_I start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊧ italic_ic. ℐ⁢(D,𝑖𝑐,t)ℐ𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑡{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},t)caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_t ) denotes the set of violation sets for 𝑖𝑐𝑖𝑐{\it ic}italic_ic that contain tuple t𝑡titalic_t. □normal-□\Box□

A violation set I𝐼Iitalic_I for 𝑖𝑐𝑖𝑐{\it ic}italic_ic is a minimal set of tuples that simultaneously participate in the violation of 𝑖𝑐𝑖𝑐{\it ic}italic_ic.

Definition 7

Given an instance D𝐷Ditalic_D and ICs IC, a local fix for t∈D𝑡𝐷t\in Ditalic_t ∈ italic_D, is a tuple t′superscript𝑡normal-′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with: (a) the same values for the rigid attributes as t𝑡titalic_t; (b) S(t,t′):={I|there is 𝑖𝑐∈𝐼𝐶,I∈ℐ(D,𝑖𝑐,t) and S(t,t^{\prime}):=\{I~{}|~{}\mbox{there is }{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}},~{}I\in{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},t)\mbox{ and }italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) := { italic_I | there is italic_ic ∈ IC , italic_I ∈ caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_t ) and ((I∖{t})∪{t′})⊧𝑖𝑐}≠∅((I\smallsetminus\{t\})\cup\{t^{\prime}\})\models{\it ic}\}~{}\neq~{}\emptyset( ( italic_I ∖ { italic_t } ) ∪ { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) ⊧ italic_ic } ≠ ∅;  and (c) there is no tuple t′′superscript𝑡normal-′′t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that simultaneously satisfies (a), S⁢(t,t′′)=S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡normal-′′𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡normal-′S(t,t^{\prime\prime})=S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), and Δ⁢({t},{t′′})≤Δ⁢({t},{t′})normal-Δ𝑡superscript𝑡normal-′′normal-Δ𝑡superscript𝑡normal-′\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})\leq\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) ≤ roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ), where Δnormal-Δ\Deltaroman_Δ denotes quadratic distance. □normal-□\Box□

S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) contains the violation sets that include t𝑡titalic_t and are solved by replacing t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for t𝑡titalic_t. A local fix t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT solves some of the violations due to t𝑡titalic_t and minimizes the distance to t𝑡titalic_t.

5.2 Database fix problem as a set cover problem

For a fixed set IC of local denials, we can solve an instance of 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP by transforming it into an instance of the Minimum Weighted Set Cover Optimization Problem (𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃\!{\it MWSCP}\!italic_MWSCP). This problem is 𝑀𝐴𝑋𝑆𝑁𝑃𝑀𝐴𝑋𝑆𝑁𝑃{\it MAXSNP}italic_MAXSNP-hard [20, 21], and its general approximation algorithms are within a logarithmic factor [20, 9]. By concentrating on local denials, we will be able to generate a version of the 𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP that can be approximated within a constant factor (c.f. Section 5.3).

Definition 8

For a database D𝐷Ditalic_D and a set IC of local denials, 𝒢⁢(D,𝐼𝐶)=(T,H)𝒢𝐷𝐼𝐶𝑇𝐻{\cal G}(D,{\textit{IC}})=(T,H)caligraphic_G ( italic_D , IC ) = ( italic_T , italic_H ) denotes the conflict hypergraph for D𝐷Ditalic_D wrt IC [8], which has in the set T𝑇Titalic_T of vertices the database tuples, and in the set H𝐻Hitalic_H of hyperedges, the violation sets for elements 𝑖𝑐∈𝐼𝐶𝑖𝑐𝐼𝐶{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic ∈ IC. □normal-□\Box□

Hyperedges in H𝐻Hitalic_H can be labelled with the corresponding 𝑖𝑐𝑖𝑐{\it ic}italic_ic, so that different hyperedges may contain the same tuples. Now we build an instance of 𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃\!{\it MWSCP}\!italic_MWSCP.

Definition 9

For a database D𝐷Ditalic_D and a set IC of local denials, the instance (U,𝒮,w)𝑈𝒮𝑤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ) for the 𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃\!{\it MWSCP}\!italic_MWSCP, where U𝑈Uitalic_U is the underlying set, 𝒮𝒮{\cal S}caligraphic_S is the set collection, and w𝑤witalic_w is the weight function, is given by: (a) U:=Hassign𝑈𝐻U:=Hitalic_U := italic_H, the set of hyperedges of 𝒢⁢(D,𝐼𝐶)𝒢𝐷𝐼𝐶{\cal G}(D,{\textit{IC}})caligraphic_G ( italic_D , IC ). (b) 𝒮𝒮{\cal S}caligraphic_S contains the S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡normal-′S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where t′superscript𝑡normal-′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a local fix for a tuple t∈D𝑡𝐷t\in Ditalic_t ∈ italic_D. (c) w⁢(S⁢(t,t′)):=Δ⁢({t},{t′})assign𝑤𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡normal-′normal-Δ𝑡superscript𝑡normal-′w(S(t,t^{\prime})):=\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})italic_w ( italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) := roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). □normal-□\Box□

It can be proved that the S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in this construction are non empty, and that 𝒮𝒮{\cal S}caligraphic_S covers U𝑈Uitalic_U (c.f. Proposition A.11 in Appendix 0.A.1).

If for the instance (U,𝒮,w)𝑈𝒮𝑤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ) of 𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP we find a minimum weight cover 𝒞𝒞\cal Ccaligraphic_C, we could think of constructing a fix by replacing each inconsistent tuple t∈D𝑡𝐷t\in Ditalic_t ∈ italic_D by a local fix t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with S⁢(t,t′)∈𝒞𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′𝒞S(t,t^{\prime})\in{\cal C}italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_C. The problem is that there might be more than one t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the key dependencies would not be respected. Fortunately, this problem can be circumvented.

Definition 10

Let 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}caligraphic_C be a cover for instance (U,𝒮,w)𝑈𝒮𝑤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ) of the 𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP associated to D,𝐼𝐶𝐷𝐼𝐶D,{\textit{IC}}italic_D , IC.  (a) 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞normal-⋆{\cal C}^{\star}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is obtained from 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}caligraphic_C as follows: For each tuple t𝑡titalic_t with local fixes t1,…,tnsubscript𝑡1normal-…subscript𝑡𝑛t_{1},\dots,t_{n}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, n>1𝑛1n>1italic_n > 1, such that S⁢(t,ti)∈𝒞𝑆𝑡subscript𝑡𝑖𝒞S(t,t_{i})\in{\cal C}italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_C, replace in 𝒞𝒞\cal Ccaligraphic_C all the S⁢(t,ti)𝑆𝑡subscript𝑡𝑖S(t,t_{i})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by a single S⁢(t,t⋆)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡normal-⋆S(t,t^{\star})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where t⋆superscript𝑡normal-⋆t^{\star}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is such that S⁢(t,t⋆)=⋃i=1nS⁢(t,ti)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡normal-⋆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑆𝑡subscript𝑡𝑖S(t,t^{\star})=\bigcup_{i=1}^{n}S(t,t_{i})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).  (b) D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) is the database instance obtained from D𝐷Ditalic_D by replacing t𝑡titalic_t by t′superscript𝑡normal-′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if S⁢(t,t′)∈𝒞⋆𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡normal-′superscript𝒞normal-⋆S(t,t^{\prime})\in{\cal C}^{\star}italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. □normal-□\Box□

It holds (c.f. Proposition A.0.A.1 in Appendix 0.A.1) that such an S⁢(t,t⋆)∈𝒮𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡⋆𝒮S(t,t^{\star})\in{\cal S}italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_S exists in part (a) of Definition 10. Notice that there, tuple t𝑡titalic_t could have other S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) outside 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}caligraphic_C. Now we can show that the reduction to 𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP keeps the value of the objective function.

Proposition 5

If 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}caligraphic_C is an optimal cover for instance (U,𝒮,w)𝑈𝒮𝑤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ) of the 𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP associated to D,𝐼𝐶𝐷𝐼𝐶D,{\textit{IC}}italic_D , IC, then D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) is an LS-fix of D𝐷Ditalic_D wrt IC, and Δ⁢(D,D⁢(𝒞))=w⁢(𝒞)=w⁢(𝒞*)normal-Δ𝐷𝐷𝒞𝑤𝒞𝑤superscript𝒞\Delta(D,D({\cal C}))=w({\cal C})=w({\cal C}^{*})roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) ) = italic_w ( caligraphic_C ) = italic_w ( caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). □normal-□\Box□

Proposition 6

For every LS-fix D′superscript𝐷normal-′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of D𝐷Ditalic_D wrt a set of local denials IC, there exists an optimal cover 𝒞𝒞\cal Ccaligraphic_C for the associated instance (U,𝒮,w)𝑈𝒮𝑤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ) of the M⁢W⁢S⁢C⁢P𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃MWSCPitalic_M italic_W italic_S italic_C italic_P, such that D′=D⁢(𝒞)superscript𝐷normal-′𝐷𝒞D^{\prime}=D({\cal C})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_D ( caligraphic_C ). □normal-□\Box□

Proposition 7

The transformation of 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP into 𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP, and the construction of database instance D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) from a cover 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}caligraphic_C for (U,𝒮,w)𝑈𝒮𝑤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ) can be done in polynomial time in the size of D𝐷Ditalic_D. □normal-□\Box□

We have established that the transformation of 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP into 𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP is an L𝐿Litalic_L-reduction [21]. Proposition 7 proves, in particular, that the number of violation sets S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is polynomially bounded by the size of the original database D𝐷Ditalic_D.

Example 7

(example 5 continued) We illustrate the reduction from 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP to 𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP. The violation sets are {t1subscript𝑡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,t4subscript𝑡4t_{4}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT} and {t1subscript𝑡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,t5subscript𝑡5t_{5}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT} for 𝐼𝐶1subscript𝐼𝐶1{\it IC}_{1}italic_IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and {t1subscript𝑡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT} and {t2subscript𝑡2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT} for 𝐼𝐶2subscript𝐼𝐶2{\it IC}_{2}italic_IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The figure shows the hypergraph. For the 𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP instance, we need the local fixes. Tuple t1subscript𝑡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has two local fixes t1′=(1,15,50)superscriptsubscript𝑡1′11550t_{1}^{\prime}=(1,15,50)italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( 1 , 15 , 50 ), that solves the violation set {t1}subscript𝑡1\{t_{1}\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of 𝐼𝐶2subscript𝐼𝐶2{\textit{IC}}_{2}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (hyperedge B), and t1′′=(1,18,52)superscriptsubscript𝑡1′′11852t_{1}^{\prime\prime}=(1,18,52)italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( 1 , 18 , 52 ), that solves the violation sets {t1,t4}subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡4\{t_{1},t_{4}\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and {t1,t5}subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡5\{t_{1},t_{5}\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of 𝐼𝐶1subscript𝐼𝐶1{\it IC}_{1}italic_IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and {t1}subscript𝑡1\{t_{1}\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of 𝐼𝐶2subscript𝐼𝐶2{\it IC}_{2}italic_IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (hyperedges A,B, C), with weights 4444 and 9999, resp. t2subscript𝑡2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, t4subscript𝑡4t_{4}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and t5subscript𝑡5t_{5}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have one local fix each corresponding to: (2,16,50)21650(2,16,50)( 2 , 16 , 50 ), (1,𝐶𝐷,25)1𝐶𝐷25(1,{\it CD},25)( 1 , italic_CD , 25 ) and (1,𝐷𝑉𝐷,25)1𝐷𝑉𝐷25(1,{\it DVD},25)( 1 , italic_DVD , 25 ), resp.  The consistent tuple t3subscript𝑡3t_{3}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has no local fix.


Set S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT S2subscript𝑆2S_{2}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT S3subscript𝑆3S_{3}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT S4subscript𝑆4S_{4}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT S5subscript𝑆5S_{5}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
