start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and equal to 00 for negative occurrence. For example, for C6=X6∨¬⁢X9∨X12subscript𝐶6subscript𝑋6subscript𝑋9subscript𝑋12C_{6}=X_{6}\lor\neg X_{9}\lor X_{12}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ ¬ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 9 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we insert (C6,X6,1,X9,0,X12,1)subscript𝐶6subscript𝑋61subscript𝑋90subscript𝑋121(C_{6},X_{6},1,X_{9},0,X_{12},1)( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 9 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 0 , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 ).

It is easy to see that all the fixes D𝐷Ditalic_D represent satisfying assignments for ψ𝜓\psiitalic_ψ, such that in case a tuple (Xi,1,0,_)subscript𝑋𝑖10_(X_{i},1,0,\_)( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 , 0 , _ ) is in a fix, then value 𝑡𝑟𝑢𝑒𝑡𝑟𝑢𝑒{\it true}italic_true must be assigned to variable Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; and value 𝑓𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒𝑓𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒{\it false}italic_false must be assigned to Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in case (Xi,0,1,_)subscript𝑋𝑖01_(X_{i},0,1,\_)( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 0 , 1 , _ ) is in the fix. If ψ𝜓\psiitalic_ψ is unsatisfiable, then there are no fixes.

Let us now consider the cost of a repair. Assume that S1=xi11,…,xim11subscript𝑆1subscript𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑖11…subscript𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑖1subscript𝑚1S_{1}=x_{i^{1}_{1}},\ldots,x_{i^{1}_{m_{1}}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and S2=xi12,…,xim22subscript𝑆2subscript𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑖21…subscript𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑖2subscript𝑚2S_{2}=x_{i^{2}_{1}},\ldots,x_{i^{2}_{m_{2}}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are satisfying assignments with S1≺S2precedessubscript𝑆1subscript𝑆2S_{1}\prec S_{2}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under lexicographical order. Since S1≺S2precedessubscript𝑆1subscript𝑆2S_{1}\prec S_{2}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there exists an integer m𝑚mitalic_m such that im1<im2subscriptsuperscript𝑖1𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑖2𝑚i^{1}_{m}<i^{2}_{m}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, while for all j<m𝑗𝑚j<mitalic_j < italic_m, ij1=ij2subscriptsuperscript𝑖1𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑖2𝑗i^{1}_{j}=i^{2}_{j}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, by definition of lexicographical order. The cost of repair S𝑆Sitalic_S is equal to 2n−i1+2ni2+⋯+2nimX+nsuperscript2𝑛subscript𝑖1superscript2subscript𝑛subscript𝑖2⋯superscript2subscript𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝑚𝑋𝑛2^{n-{i_{1}}}+2^{n_{i_{2}}}+\cdots+2^{n_{i_{m_{X}}}}+n2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ⋯ + 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_n, because (a) we have to update attribute 𝑤𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡𝑤𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡{\it weight}italic_weight for each variable that is assigned value 𝑡𝑟𝑢𝑒𝑡𝑟𝑢𝑒{\it true}italic_true, and (b) for each tuple in relation 𝑉𝑎𝑟𝑉𝑎𝑟{\it Var}italic_Var, attribute 𝑡𝑟𝑡𝑟{\it tr}italic_tr or attribute 𝑓𝑎𝑓𝑎{\it fa}italic_fa is changed by 1111.

Because of (a), there exists a term 2n−im1superscript2𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑖1𝑚2^{n-i^{1}_{m}}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the cost of S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that is bigger than the sum of all terms in S2subscript𝑆2S_{2}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with index ≥im2absentsubscriptsuperscript𝑖2𝑚\geq i^{2}_{m}≥ italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. So, the cost of the fix representing S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is greater than the cost of the fix representing S2subscript𝑆2S_{2}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In consequence, the minimal fix would be the maximum according to the lexicographical order of satisfying assignments.

The answer to the ground atomic query 𝑉𝑎𝑟⁢(Xn,1,0,1)𝑉𝑎𝑟subscript𝑋𝑛101{\it Var}(X_{n},1,0,1)italic_Var ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 , 0 , 1 ) is true iff Xnsubscript𝑋𝑛X_{n}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT takes the value 1111 in the l.o. greatest assignment. □□\Box□

Proof of Theorem 4.5: The reduction can be established with a fixed set 𝐼𝐶0subscript𝐼𝐶0{\textit{IC}}_{0}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ICs. Given an undirected graph 𝒢=(𝒱,ℰ)𝒢𝒱ℰ{\cal G}=({\cal V},{\cal E})caligraphic_G = ( caligraphic_V , caligraphic_E ), consider a database with relations V⁢(X,Z),E⁢(U,W)𝑉𝑋𝑍𝐸𝑈𝑊V(X,Z),E(U,W)italic_V ( italic_X , italic_Z ) , italic_E ( italic_U , italic_W ), where X𝑋Xitalic_X is a key and Z𝑍Zitalic_Z is the only fixable attribute and takes values in {0,1}01\{0,1\}{ 0 , 1 } (which can be enforced by means of the linear denials ∀X⁢∀Z⁢¬⁡(V⁢(X,Z),Z>1)for-all𝑋for-all𝑍𝑉𝑋𝑍𝑍1\forall X\forall Z\neg(V(X,Z),Z>1)∀ italic_X ∀ italic_Z ¬ ( italic_V ( italic_X , italic_Z ) , italic_Z > 1 ), ∀X⁢∀Z⁢¬⁡(V⁢(X,Z),Z<0)for-all𝑋for-all𝑍𝑉𝑋𝑍𝑍0\forall X\forall Z\neg(V(X,Z),Z<0)∀ italic_X ∀ italic_Z ¬ ( italic_V ( italic_X , italic_Z ) , italic_Z < 0 ) in 𝐼𝐶0subscript𝐼𝐶0{\textit{IC}}_{0}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Intuitively, Z𝑍Zitalic_Z indicates with 1111 if the vertex X𝑋Xitalic_X is in the cover, and with 00 otherwise. Attributes U,V𝑈𝑉U,Vitalic_U , italic_V are vertices and then, non numerical.

In the original database D𝐷Ditalic_D we have the tuples V⁢(e,0)𝑉𝑒0V(e,0)italic_V ( italic_e , 0 ), with e∈𝒱𝑒𝒱e\in{\cal V}italic_e ∈ caligraphic_V; and also the tuples E(e1,E(e_{1},italic_E ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , e2)e_{2})italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for (e1,(e_{1},( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , e2)∈ℰe_{2})\in{\cal E}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_E. Given the linear constraint

∀X1⁢Z1⁢X2⁢Z2⁢¬⁡(V⁢(X1,Z1),V⁢(X2,Z2),E⁢(X1,X2),Z1=0,Z2=0)for-allsubscript𝑋1subscript𝑍1subscript𝑋2subscript𝑍2𝑉subscript𝑋1subscript𝑍1𝑉subscript𝑋2subscript𝑍2𝐸subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2subscript𝑍10subscript𝑍20\forall X_{1}Z_{1}X_{2}Z_{2}\neg(V(X_{1},Z_{1}),V(X_{2},Z_{2}),E(X_{1},X_{2}),Z_{1}=0,Z_{2}=0)∀ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ¬ ( italic_V ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_V ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_E ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 )

in 𝐼𝐶0subscript𝐼𝐶0{\textit{IC}}_{0}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the LS-fixes of the database are in one-to-one correspondence with the vertex covers of minimal cardinality.

For the query Q(k):q⁢(s⁢u⁢m⁢(Z)),s⁢u⁢m⁢(Z)<k:superscript𝑄𝑘𝑞𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑍𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑍𝑘Q^{(k)}\!:q(sum(Z)),sum(Z)<kitalic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_q ( italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_Z ) ) , italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_Z ) < italic_k, with q⁢(s⁢u⁢m⁢(Z))←V⁢(X,Z)←𝑞𝑠𝑢𝑚𝑍𝑉𝑋𝑍q(sum(Z))\leftarrow V(X,Z)italic_q ( italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_Z ) ) ← italic_V ( italic_X , italic_Z ), the instance (D,𝑦𝑒𝑠)𝐷𝑦𝑒𝑠(D,{\it yes})( italic_D , italic_yes ) for consistent query answering under brave semantics has answer No, (i.e. Q(k)superscript𝑄𝑘Q^{(k)}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is false in all LS-fixes) only for every k𝑘kitalic_k smaller than the minimum cardinality c𝑐citalic_c of a vertex cover. □□\Box□

In the previous proof, the first two ICs in 𝐼𝐶0subscript𝐼𝐶0{\it IC}_{0}italic_IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be eliminated, and the third one is local (c.f. Definition 5). In consequence, the theorem also holds for local denials.

Proof of Proposition 3: By reduction from the 𝑀𝐴𝑋𝑆𝑁𝑃𝑀𝐴𝑋𝑆𝑁𝑃{\it MAXSNP}italic_MAXSNP-hard problem B-Minimum Vertex Cover (BMVC), which asks to find a minimum vertex cover in a graph whose nodes have a bounded degree [16, chap. 10]. We start by encoding the graph as in the proof of Theorem 4.5. We also use the same initial database D𝐷Ditalic_D. Every LS-fix D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of D𝐷Ditalic_D corresponds to a minimum vertex cover 𝒱′superscript𝒱′{\cal V}^{\prime}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}caligraphic_G and vice versa, and it holds |𝒱′|=Δ⁢(D,D′)superscript𝒱′Δ𝐷superscript𝐷′|{\cal V}^{\prime}|=\Delta(D,D^{\prime})| caligraphic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | = roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). This gives us an L𝐿Litalic_L-reduction from BMVC to 𝐷𝐹𝑃𝐷𝐹𝑃{\it DFP}italic_DFP [21]. □□\Box□


Lemma A.2. Given a database D𝐷Ditalic_D and a set of consistent local denials IC, there will always exist an LS-fix D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of D𝐷Ditalic_D wrt IC. □□\Box□

Proof:  As shown in proof of Lemma A.0.A.1 for every fixable attribute in F𝐹Fitalic_F it is possible to define, using the integrity constraints in IC, an interval [cl,cu]subscript𝑐𝑙subscript𝑐𝑢[c_{l},c_{u}][ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] such that if the value of attribute A𝐴Aitalic_A is in that interval there is no constraint 𝑖𝑐∈𝐼𝐶𝑖𝑐𝐼𝐶{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic ∈ IC with a built-in involving A𝐴Aitalic_A such that ℐ⁢(D,𝑖𝑐,t)≠∅ℐ𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑡{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},t)\neq\emptysetcaligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_t ) ≠ ∅. Let D′′superscript𝐷′′D^{\prime\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a database constructed in the following way: for every tuple t∈D𝑡𝐷t\in Ditalic_t ∈ italic_D such that the value of a fixable attribute does not belong to its interval, replace its value by any value in the interval. Clearly D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will be a fix but will not necessarily be an LS-fix. By Proposition 1 we know there exists an LS-fix D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for D𝐷Ditalic_D wrt IC. □□\Box□

Definition 11

Given a database D𝐷Ditalic_D and a set of ICs IC, a local fix t′superscript𝑡normal-′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for a tuple t𝑡titalic_t does not generate new violations if ⋃𝑖𝑐∈𝐼𝐶(⋃l∈D′ℐ(D′,𝑖𝑐,l)\bigcup_{{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}}(\bigcup_{l\in D^{\prime}}{\cal I}(D^{\prime},{\it ic},l)⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ic ∈ IC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ∈ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ic , italic_l ) ∖\smallsetminus∖ ⋃l∈Dℐ(D,𝑖𝑐,l))=∅\bigcup_{l\in D}{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},l))=\emptyset⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ∈ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_l ) ) = ∅  for  D′=(D∖{t})∪{t′}superscript𝐷normal-′𝐷𝑡superscript𝑡normal-′D^{\prime}=(D\smallsetminus\{t\})\cup\{t^{\prime}\}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_D ∖ { italic_t } ) ∪ { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }. □normal-□\Box□


Lemma A.3. For a set IC of local denials, if t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a local fix of a tuple t𝑡titalic_t, then t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does not generate new violations444c.f. Definition 11 in database D𝐷Ditalic_D wrt IC. Furthermore, this holds also for t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT a “relaxed” local fix where the distance to t𝑡titalic_t is not necessarily minimal □□\Box□

Proof: Tuple t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can only differ from t𝑡titalic_t in the value of fixable attributes. Let us assume that one of the modified values was for an attribute A𝐴Aitalic_A. Since we have local constraints, attribute A𝐴Aitalic_A can only be in the constraints related either to <<< and ≤\leq≤ or to >>> and ≥\geq≥, but not both. Without lost of generality, we will assume that the constraint is written as in equation 1 and that A𝐴Aitalic_A is related only to >>> and ≥\geq≥. Since t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a local fix, S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is not empty and there is a set 𝐼𝐶tsubscript𝐼𝐶𝑡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of constraints for which t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT solves the inconsistency in which t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT was involved. There is an interval [cl,+∞)subscript𝑐𝑙[c_{l},+\infty)[ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , + ∞ ) for A𝐴Aitalic_A that can be obtained by the limits given in 𝐼𝐶tsubscript𝐼𝐶𝑡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that show the values of A𝐴Aitalic_A that would force the satisfaction of the constraints in 𝐼𝐶tsubscript𝐼𝐶𝑡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that have attribute A𝐴Aitalic_A in an inequality. This shows that the value of attribute A𝐴Aitalic_A in t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is bigger than the value of A𝐴Aitalic_A in t𝑡titalic_t.

For D′=(D∖{t})∪{t′}superscript𝐷′𝐷𝑡superscript𝑡′D^{\prime}=(D\smallsetminus\{t\})\cup\{t^{\prime}\}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_D ∖ { italic_t } ) ∪ { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } we need to prove that ⋃𝑖𝑐∈𝐼𝐶(⋃l∈D′ℐ(D′,𝑖𝑐,l)∖\bigcup_{{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}}(\bigcup_{l\in D^{\prime}}{\cal I}(D^{\prime},{\it ic},l)~{}\smallsetminus~{}⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ic ∈ IC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ∈ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ic , italic_l ) ∖ ⋃l∈Dℐ(D,𝑖𝑐,l))=∅\bigcup_{l\in D}{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},l))=\emptyset⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ∈ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_l ) ) = ∅. By contradiction let us assume that for a constraint 𝑖𝑐∈𝐼𝐶𝑖𝑐𝐼𝐶{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic ∈ IC there exists a violation set I𝐼Iitalic_I such that I∈⋃l∈D′ℐ⁢(D′,𝑖𝑐,l)𝐼subscript𝑙superscript𝐷′ℐsuperscript𝐷′𝑖𝑐𝑙I\in\bigcup_{l\in D^{\prime}}{\cal I}(D^{\prime},{\it ic},l)italic_I ∈ ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ∈ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ic , italic_l ) and I∉⋃l∈Dℐ⁢(D,𝑖𝑐,l)𝐼subscript𝑙𝐷ℐ𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑙I\not\in\bigcup_{l\in D}{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},l)italic_I ∉ ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ∈ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_l ). There are two cases to consider (with (I,𝑖𝑐(I,{\it ic}( italic_I , italic_ic, we indicate that I𝐼Iitalic_I is a violation set for IC 𝑖𝑐𝑖𝑐{\it ic}italic_ic):

  • •

    (I,𝑖𝑐)∈S⁢(t,t′)𝐼𝑖𝑐𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′(I,{\it ic})\in S(t,t^{\prime})( italic_I , italic_ic ) ∈ italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then I∈ℐ⁢(D,i⁢c,t)𝐼ℐ𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑡I\in{\cal I}(D,ic,t)italic_I ∈ caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_i italic_c , italic_t ), but since we wanted an I∉⋃l∈Dℐ(D,I\not\in\bigcup_{l\in D}{\cal I}(D,italic_I ∉ ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ∈ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( italic_D , 𝑖𝑐,l){\it ic},l)italic_ic , italic_l ) this is not possible.

  • •

    (I,𝑖𝑐)∉S⁢(t,t′)𝐼𝑖𝑐𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′(I,{\it ic})\not\in S(t,t^{\prime})( italic_I , italic_ic ) ∉ italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then we have two possibilities I∉ℐ⁢(D,i⁢c,t)𝐼ℐ𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑡I\not\in{\cal I}(D,ic,t)italic_I ∉ caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_i italic_c , italic_t ) or ((I∖{t})∪{t′})⊧̸i⁢cnot-models𝐼𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑖𝑐((I\smallsetminus\{t\})\cup\{t^{\prime}\})\not\models ic( ( italic_I ∖ { italic_t } ) ∪ { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) ⊧̸ italic_i italic_c.

    • –

      Let us consider first that I∉ℐ⁢(D,i⁢c,t)𝐼ℐ𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑡I\not\in{\cal I}(D,ic,t)italic_I ∉ caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_i italic_c , italic_t ). We have that I∈⋃l∈D′ℐ(D′,I\in\bigcup_{l\in D^{\prime}}{\cal I}(D^{\prime},italic_I ∈ ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ∈ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 𝑖𝑐,l){\it ic},l)italic_ic , italic_l ) and since t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the only difference between D𝐷Ditalic_D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we have I∈ℐ⁢(D′,𝑖𝑐,t′)𝐼ℐsuperscript𝐷′𝑖𝑐superscript𝑡′I\in{\cal I}(D^{\prime},{\it ic},t^{\prime})italic_I ∈ caligraphic_I ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ic , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Since all the constraints can only have attribute A𝐴Aitalic_A with >>> or ≥\geq≥ we now that in particular 𝑖𝑐𝑖𝑐{\it ic}italic_ic does. Since I∉ℐ⁢(D,i⁢c,t)𝐼ℐ𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑡I\not\in{\cal I}(D,ic,t)italic_I ∉ caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_i italic_c , italic_t ) we know that A𝐴Aitalic_A satisfied the condition in 𝑖𝑐𝑖𝑐{\it ic}italic_ic and since we know that t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a bigger value than in t𝑡titalic_t, it is not possible to generate an inconsistency in D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We have reached a contradiction.

    • –

      Let us consider ((I∖{t})∪{t′})⊧̸i⁢cnot-models𝐼𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑖𝑐((I\smallsetminus\{t\})\cup\{t^{\prime}\})\not\models ic( ( italic_I ∖ { italic_t } ) ∪ { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) ⊧̸ italic_i italic_c. Then I∈ℐ⁢(D′,i⁢c,t′)𝐼ℐsuperscript𝐷′𝑖𝑐superscript𝑡′I\in{\cal I}(D^{\prime},ic,t^{\prime})italic_I ∈ caligraphic_I ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_i italic_c , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). From our assumption I∉⋃l∈Dℐ⁢(D,𝑖𝑐,l)𝐼subscript𝑙𝐷ℐ𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑙I\not\in\bigcup_{l\in D}{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},l)italic_I ∉ ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ∈ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_l ).This is the same situation analyzed in previous item.

In all the cases we have reached contradiction and therefore the proposition is proved. Since we never used the property of minimal distance between t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and t𝑡titalic_t, the second part of the Lemma is also proved. □□\Box□


Proposition A.2. For local denials it always exists an LS-fix for a database D𝐷Ditalic_D; and for every LS-fix D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, D′∖Dsuperscript𝐷′𝐷D^{\prime}\smallsetminus Ditalic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ italic_D is a set of local fixes. Furthermore, for each violation set (I,𝑖𝑐)𝐼𝑖𝑐(I,{\it ic})( italic_I , italic_ic ), there is a tuple t∈I𝑡𝐼t\in Iitalic_t ∈ italic_I and a local fix t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for t𝑡titalic_t, such that (I,𝑖𝑐)∈S⁢(t,t′)𝐼𝑖𝑐𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′(I,{\it ic})\in S(t,t^{\prime})( italic_I , italic_ic ) ∈ italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). □□\Box□

Proof:  Since each attribute A can only be associated to <<< or >>> built-ins, but not both, it is clear that set of local denials is always consistent. By Lemma A.0.A.1, there always exists an LS-fix D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Now we need to prove that D′∖Dsuperscript𝐷′𝐷D^{\prime}\smallsetminus Ditalic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ italic_D is a set of local fixes. By contradiction assume that t′∈(D′∖D)superscript𝑡′superscript𝐷′𝐷t^{\prime}\in(D^{\prime}\smallsetminus D)italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ italic_D ) is not a local fix of the tuple t𝑡titalic_t. This can happen in the following situations:

  • •

    t𝑡titalic_t was consistent. From Lemma A.0.A.1 we know that no new inconsistencies can be added by the modifications done to the other tuples and therefore t𝑡titalic_t is not related to any inconsistency. Then D⋆=D′∖{t′}∪{t}superscript𝐷⋆superscript𝐷′superscript𝑡′𝑡D^{\star}=D^{\prime}\smallsetminus\{t^{\prime}\}\cup\{t\}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ∪ { italic_t } is also consistent and Δ⁢(D,D⋆)<Δ⁢(D,D′)Δ𝐷superscript𝐷⋆Δ𝐷superscript𝐷′\Delta(D,D^{\star})<\Delta(D,D^{\prime})roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). But D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an LS-fix so this is not possible.

  • •

    t𝑡titalic_t is involved at least in one violation set. If S⁢(t,t′)=∅𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})=\emptysetitalic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ∅ then t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not solving any violation set and therefore D⋆=D′∖{t′}∪{t}superscript𝐷⋆superscript𝐷′superscript𝑡′𝑡D^{\star}=D^{\prime}\smallsetminus\{t^{\prime}\}\cup\{t\}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ∪ { italic_t } is also consistent and Δ⁢(D,D⋆)<Δ⁢(D,D′)Δ𝐷superscript𝐷⋆Δ𝐷superscript𝐷′\Delta(D,D^{\star})<\Delta(D,D^{\prime})roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). But D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an LS-fix so this is not possible. Now, if S⁢(t,t′)≠∅𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})\neq\emptysetitalic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≠ ∅, from Lemma A.0.A.1, considering D={t}𝐷𝑡D=\{t\}italic_D = { italic_t } and 𝐼𝐶={𝑖𝑐|(I,𝑖𝑐)∈S⁢(t,t′)}𝐼𝐶conditional-set𝑖𝑐𝐼𝑖𝑐𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′{\textit{IC}}=\{{\it ic}|(I,{\it ic})\in S(t,t^{\prime})\}IC = { italic_ic | ( italic_I , italic_ic ) ∈ italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) }, there exists an LS-fix D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of D𝐷Ditalic_D, i.e. there exists a local fix t′′superscript𝑡′′t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that S⁢(t,t′′)=S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′′𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime\prime})=S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Since t′′superscript𝑡′′t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a local fix we know that Δ⁢({t},{t′′})≤Δ⁢({t},{t′})Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})\leq\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) ≤ roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). They cannot be equal that would imply that t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a local fix and it is not. Then D⋆=D′∖{t′}∪{t}superscript𝐷⋆superscript𝐷′superscript𝑡′𝑡D^{\star}=D^{\prime}\smallsetminus\{t^{\prime}\}\cup\{t\}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ∪ { italic_t } is also consistent and Δ⁢(D,D⋆)<Δ⁢(D,D′)Δ𝐷superscript𝐷⋆Δ𝐷superscript𝐷′\Delta(D,D^{\star})<\Delta(D,D^{\prime})roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Again, this is not possible because D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an LS-fix

The second part of the proposition can be proved using Lemma A.0.A.1 and considering a database D=I𝐷𝐼D=Iitalic_D = italic_I and a set of constraints 𝐼𝐶={𝑖𝑐}𝐼𝐶𝑖𝑐{\textit{IC}}=\{{\it ic}\}IC = { italic_ic }. □□\Box□

Proof of Proposition 4: For the first claim, membership follows from Theorem 4.2(b); and for hardness, we can do the same reduction as in Theorem 4.2(b), because the ICs used there are local denials. For the second claim, it is not difficult to see that the non-local denials in the proof of Proposition 3 can be eliminated. □□\Box□


Proposition A.3. For a database D𝐷Ditalic_D and a set of local denial constraints IC:

  1. 1.

    For a set of local fixes {t1,…⁢tn}subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡𝑛\{t_{1},\dots t_{n}\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of a tuple t𝑡titalic_t there always exists a local fix t⋆superscript𝑡⋆t^{\star}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that S⁢(t,t⋆)=⋃i=1nS⁢(t,ti)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡⋆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑆𝑡subscript𝑡𝑖S(t,t^{\star})=\bigcup_{i=1}^{n}S(t,t_{i})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

  2. 2.

    For local fixes t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, t′′superscript𝑡′′t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and t′′′superscript𝑡′′′t^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of a tuple t𝑡titalic_t with S⁢(t,t′′′)=S⁢(t,t′)∪S⁢(t,t′′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′′′𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′′S(t,t^{\prime\prime\prime})=S(t,t^{\prime})\cup S(t,t^{\prime\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∪ italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), it holds that Δ⁢({t},{t′′′})≤Δ⁢({t},{t′})+Δ⁢({t},{t′′})Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime\prime}\})\leq\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})+\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) ≤ roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) + roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). □□\Box□

Proof: First we prove item (1). Let ICt={𝑖𝑐|ℐ(D,𝑖𝑐,t)≠∅IC_{t}=\{{\it ic}|{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},t)\neq\emptysetitalic_I italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_ic | caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_t ) ≠ ∅ and I⁢CS⁢(t,t′)={𝑖𝑐|(I,𝑖𝑐)∈S⁢(t,t′)}𝐼subscript𝐶𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′conditional-set𝑖𝑐𝐼𝑖𝑐𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′IC_{S}(t,t^{\prime})=\{{\it ic}|(I,{\it ic})\in S(t,t^{\prime})\}italic_I italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = { italic_ic | ( italic_I , italic_ic ) ∈ italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) }. From Lemma A.0.A.1, considering D={t}𝐷𝑡D=\{t\}italic_D = { italic_t } and IC any subset of 𝐼𝐶tsubscript𝐼𝐶𝑡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there always exists an LS-fix D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of D𝐷Ditalic_D. This LS-fix is a local fix of tuple t𝑡titalic_t with I⁢CS⁢(t,t′)=𝐼𝐶𝐼subscript𝐶𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′𝐼𝐶IC_{S}(t,t^{\prime})={\textit{IC}}italic_I italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = IC. Since we can find a local fix for any 𝐼𝐶⊆St𝐼𝐶subscript𝑆𝑡{\textit{IC}}\subseteq S_{t}IC ⊆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT then clearly the lemma can be satisfied.

Now we will prove item (2). If the fixable attributes that where modified in t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and t′′superscript𝑡′′t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are disjoint, then t′′′superscript𝑡′′′t^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT when combining the modifications I’ll get Δ⁢({t},{t′′′})=Δ⁢({t},{t′})+Δ⁢({t},{t′′})Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime\prime}\})=\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})+\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) = roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) + roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). Now, we will consider the case were t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and t′′superscript𝑡′′t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have at least one fixable attribute, say A𝐴Aitalic_A that is modified by both local fixes. In this case t′′′superscript𝑡′′′t^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will have a value in A𝐴Aitalic_A that solves the inconsistencies solved by and t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and t′′superscript𝑡′′t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This value will in fact correspond to the value of A𝐴Aitalic_A in t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or t′′superscript𝑡′′t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and therefore we will have that Δ⁢({t},{t′′′})<Δ⁢({t},{t′})+Δ⁢({t},{t′′})Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime\prime}\})<\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})+\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) < roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) + roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). Let M𝑀Mitalic_M be the set of attributes that are modified both by t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and t′′superscript𝑡′′t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we can express the relation as follows: Δ⁢({t},{t′′′})=∑A∈ℱ(πA⁢(t)−πA⁢(t′′′))2Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′′subscript𝐴ℱsuperscriptsubscript𝜋𝐴𝑡subscript𝜋𝐴superscript𝑡′′′2\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime\prime}\})=\sum_{A\in{\cal F}}(\pi_{\!A}(t)-\pi_{\!A}(t^{\prime\prime\prime}))^{2}roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A ∈ caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =∑A∈ℱ(πA⁢(t)−πA⁢(t′))2absentsubscript𝐴ℱsuperscriptsubscript𝜋𝐴𝑡subscript𝜋𝐴superscript𝑡′2=\sum_{A\in{\cal F}}(\pi_{\!A}(t)-\pi_{\!A}(t^{\prime}))^{2}= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A ∈ caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT +∑A∈ℱ(πA⁢(t)−πA⁢(t′′))2subscript𝐴ℱsuperscriptsubscript𝜋𝐴𝑡subscript𝜋𝐴superscript𝑡′′2+\sum_{A\in{\cal F}}(\pi_{\!A}(t)-\pi_{\!A}(t^{\prime\prime}))^{2}+ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A ∈ caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT −∑A∈ℳM⁢i⁢n⁢{(πA⁢(t)−πA⁢(t′))2,(πA⁢(t)−πA⁢(t′′))2}subscript𝐴ℳ𝑀𝑖𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜋𝐴𝑡subscript𝜋𝐴superscript𝑡′2superscriptsubscript𝜋𝐴𝑡subscript𝜋𝐴superscript𝑡′′2-\sum_{A\in{\cal M}}Min\{(\pi_{\!A}(t)-\pi_{\!A}(t^{\prime}))^{2},(\pi_{\!A}(t)-\pi_{\!A}(t^{\prime\prime}))^{2}\}- ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A ∈ caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_i italic_n { ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } □□\Box□


Proposition A.4. If an optimal cover 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}caligraphic_C for the instance (U,𝒮)𝑈𝒮(U,{\cal S})( italic_U , caligraphic_S ) of M⁢W⁢S⁢C⁢P𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃MWSCPitalic_M italic_W italic_S italic_C italic_P has more than one S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for a tuple t𝑡titalic_t, then there exists another optimal cover 𝒞′superscript𝒞′{\cal C^{\prime}}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for (U,𝒮)𝑈𝒮(U,{\cal S})( italic_U , caligraphic_S ) with the same total weight as 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}caligraphic_C but with only one t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that S⁢(t,t′)∈𝒞𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′𝒞S(t,t^{\prime})\in{\cal C}italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_C. Furthermore, D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) is an LS-fix of D𝐷Ditalic_D wrt IC with Δ⁢(D,D⁢(𝒞))Δ𝐷𝐷𝒞\Delta(D,D(\cal C))roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) ) equal to the total weight of the cover 𝒞𝒞\cal Ccaligraphic_C. □□\Box□

Proof: To prove the first part, let us assume that S⁢(t,t′),S⁢(t,t′′)∈𝒞𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′′𝒞S(t,t^{\prime}),S(t,t^{\prime\prime})\in{\cal C}italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_C. From Proposition A.0.A.1 there exists an S⁢(t,t′′′)∈𝒮𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′′′𝒮S(t,t^{\prime\prime\prime})\in{\cal S}italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_S such that S⁢(t,t′′′)=S⁢(t,t′)∪S⁢(t,t′′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′′′𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′′S(t,t^{\prime\prime\prime})=S(t,t^{\prime})\cup S(t,t^{\prime\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∪ italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), i.e such that it covers the same elements as S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and S⁢(t,t′′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′′S(t,t^{\prime\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). ¿From Proposition A.0.A.1 Δ⁢({t},{t′′′})≤Δ⁢({t},{t′})+Δ⁢({t},{t′′})Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime\prime}\})\leq\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})+\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) ≤ roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) + roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) and therefore that weight of S⁢(t,t′′′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′′′S(t,t^{\prime\prime\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is smaller or equal than the sum of the weight of the original two sets. If Δ⁢({t},{t′′′})<Δ⁢({t},{t′})+Δ⁢({t},{t′′})Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime\prime}\})<\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})+\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) < roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) + roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) we would have that 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}caligraphic_C is not an optimal solution so this is not possible. Then Δ⁢({t},{t′′′})=Δ⁢({t},{t′})+Δ⁢({t},{t′′})Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′′\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime\prime}\})=\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})+\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) = roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) + roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). Then, if we define 𝒞′=(𝒞∖{S⁢(t,t′),S⁢(t,t′′)})∪{S⁢(t,t′′′)}superscript𝒞′𝒞𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′′𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′′′{\cal C^{\prime}}=({\cal C}\smallsetminus\{S(t,t^{\prime}),S(t,t^{\prime\prime})\})\cup\{S(t,t^{\prime\prime\prime})\}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( caligraphic_C ∖ { italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } ) ∪ { italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } we will cover all the elements and we will have the same optimal weight.

Now we need to prove that given D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) is an LS-fix. D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) is obtained by first calculating 𝒞′superscript𝒞′{\cal C}^{\prime}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and therefore we have an optimal cover with at most one S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for each tuple t𝑡titalic_t. Then D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) is obtained by replacing t𝑡titalic_t by t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for each S⁢(t,t′)∈𝒞𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′𝒞S(t,t^{\prime})\in{\cal C}italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_C. It is direct that D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) has the same schema as D𝐷Ditalic_D and that it satisfies the key constraints. Now, since 𝒞′superscript𝒞′\cal C^{\prime}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT covers all the elements, all the inconsistencies in D𝐷Ditalic_D are solved in D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ). From Lemma A.0.A.1 the local fixes t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT do not add new violations and therefore D⁢(𝒞)⊧𝐼𝐶models𝐷𝒞𝐼𝐶D({\cal C})\models{\textit{IC}}italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) ⊧ IC and D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) is a fix. We are only missing to prove that D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) minimizes the distance from D𝐷Ditalic_D. Clearly Δ⁢(D,D⁢(𝒞))=∑t∈DΔ⁢({t},{t′})Δ𝐷𝐷𝒞subscript𝑡𝐷Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′\Delta(D,D({\cal C}))=\sum_{t\in D}\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) =∑S⁢(t,t′)∈𝒞′wS⁢(t,t′)absentsubscript𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′superscript𝒞′subscript𝑤𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′=\sum_{S(t,t^{\prime})\in{\cal C^{\prime}}}w_{S(t,t^{\prime})}= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =∑S⁢(t,t′)∈𝒞wS⁢(t,t′)=wabsentsubscript𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′𝒞subscript𝑤𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑤=\sum_{S(t,t^{\prime})\in{\cal C}}w_{S(t,t^{\prime})}=w= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_w. So, since the optimal solution minimizes w𝑤witalic_w, Δ⁢(D,D⁢(𝒞))Δ𝐷𝐷𝒞\Delta(D,D({\cal C}))roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) ) is minimum and D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) is an LS-fix. □□\Box□

Proof of Proposition 5: From Propositions A.0.A.1 and A.11. □□\Box□

Proof of Proposition 6: To prove it it is enough to construct this optimal cover. Let 𝒞={S(t,t′)|t′∈(D′∖D){\cal C}=\{S(t,t^{\prime})|t^{\prime}\in(D^{\prime}\smallsetminus D)caligraphic_C = { italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ italic_D ). By definition 𝒞′=𝒞superscript𝒞′𝒞{\cal C}^{\prime}={\cal C}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = caligraphic_C and D⁢(𝒞)=D′𝐷𝒞superscript𝐷′D({\cal C})=D^{\prime}italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) = italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We need to prove that 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}caligraphic_C is an optimal cover. Since D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is consistent, all the violation sets were solved and therefore 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}caligraphic_C is a cover. Also, since Δ⁢(D,D′)=Δ⁢(D,D⁢(𝒞))=wΔ𝐷superscript𝐷′Δ𝐷𝐷𝒞𝑤\Delta(D,D^{\prime})=\Delta(D,D({\cal C}))=wroman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) ) = italic_w and Δ⁢(D,D′)Δ𝐷superscript𝐷′\Delta(D,D^{\prime})roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is minimum, 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}caligraphic_C minimizes the weight and therefore is an optimal cover. □□\Box□

Proof of Proposition 7: We have to establish that the transformation of 𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃𝐷𝐹𝑂𝑃{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP into 𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃𝑀𝑊𝑆𝐶𝑃{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP given above is an L𝐿Litalic_L-reduction [21]. So, it remains to verify that the reduction can be done in polynomial time in the size of instance D𝐷Ditalic_D for 𝐷𝐹𝑃⁢(𝐼𝐶)𝐷𝐹𝑃𝐼𝐶{\it DFP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFP ( IC ), i.e. that 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}caligraphic_G can be computed in polynomial time in n𝑛nitalic_n, the number of tuples in D𝐷Ditalic_D. Notice that if misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the number of database atoms in 𝑖𝑐i∈I⁢Csubscript𝑖𝑐𝑖𝐼𝐶{\it ic}_{i}\in ICitalic_ic start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_I italic_C, and m𝑚mitalic_m the maximum value of misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT there are at most nmisuperscript𝑛subscript𝑚𝑖n^{m_{i}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT hyperedges associated to 𝑖𝑐i∈𝐼𝐶subscript𝑖𝑐𝑖𝐼𝐶{\it ic}_{i}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ IC, each of them having between 1111 to m𝑚mitalic_m tuples. We can check that the number of sets S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and their weights are polynomially bounded by the size of D𝐷Ditalic_D. There is one S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for each local fix. Each tuple may have no more than |ℱ|×|𝐼𝐶|ℱ𝐼𝐶|{\cal F}|\times|{\textit{IC}}|| caligraphic_F | × | IC | local fixes, where ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F is the set of fixable attributes.

The weight of each S⁢(t,t′)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is polynomially bounded by the maximum absolute value in an attribute in the database and the maximum absolute value of a constant appearing in IC (by an argument similar to the one given in the proof of Proposition 4.2).

With respect to D⁢(𝒞)𝐷𝒞D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ), the number of sets in 𝒮𝒮\cal Scaligraphic_S is polynomially bounded by the size of D𝐷Ditalic_D, and since 𝒞⊆𝒮𝒞𝒮\cal C\subseteq Scaligraphic_C ⊆ caligraphic_S, 𝒞𝒞\cal Ccaligraphic_C is also polynomially bounded by the size of D𝐷Ditalic_D. To generate 𝒞′superscript𝒞′\cal C^{\prime}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT it is necessary to search through 𝒮𝒮\cal Scaligraphic_S. Finally, in order to replace t𝑡titalic_t in D𝐷Ditalic_D for each tuple t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that S⁢(t,t′)∈𝒞𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′𝒞S(t,t^{\prime})\in{\cal C}italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_C we need to search through D𝐷Ditalic_D. □□\Box□

Proof of Proposition 8: Using the same arguments as in the proof of Proposition A.11 we have that since 𝒞^^𝒞\hat{{\cal C}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG is a cover then D⁢(𝒞^)𝐷^𝒞D({\hat{\cal C}})italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) is a fix of D𝐷Ditalic_D wrt IC. We need to prove that Δ⁢(D,D⁢(𝒞^))≤l⁢o⁢g⁢(N)×Δ⁢(D,D′)Δ𝐷𝐷^𝒞𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑁Δ𝐷superscript𝐷′\Delta(D,D(\hat{\cal C}))\leq log(N)\times\Delta(D,D^{\prime})roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) ) ≤ italic_l italic_o italic_g ( italic_N ) × roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). We know that Δ⁢(D,D⁢(𝒞^))=∑t∈DΔ⁢({t},{t′})Δ𝐷𝐷^𝒞subscript𝑡𝐷Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′\Delta(D,D({\cal\hat{C}}))=\sum_{t\in D}\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). =∑S⁢(t,t′)∈𝒞^⋆wS⁢(t,t′)absentsubscript𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′superscript^𝒞⋆subscript𝑤𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′=\sum_{S(t,t^{\prime})\in\hat{\cal C}^{\star}}w_{S(t,t^{\prime})}= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As described in definition 10, 𝒞^⋆superscript^𝒞⋆\hat{\cal C}^{\star}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is obtained from 𝒞^^𝒞\hat{\cal C}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG by replacing, for each t𝑡titalic_t, all the sets S⁢(t,ti)∈𝒞^𝑆𝑡subscript𝑡𝑖^𝒞S(t,t_{i})\in\hat{\cal C}italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG by a unique set S⁢(t,t⋆)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡⋆S(t,t^{\star})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) such that S⁢(t,t⋆)=⋃iS⁢(t,ti)𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡⋆subscript𝑖𝑆𝑡subscript𝑡𝑖S(t,t^{\star})=\bigcup_{i}S(t,t_{i})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Since we are using euclidian distance to calculate the local fixes, Δ⁢({t},{t⋆})≤∑iΔ⁢({t},{ti})Δ𝑡superscript𝑡⋆subscript𝑖Δ𝑡subscript𝑡𝑖\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\star}\})\leq\sum_{i}\Delta(\{t\},\{t_{i}\})roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) ≤ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ). Then,

Δ⁢(D,D⁢(𝒞^))=∑S⁢(t,t′)∈𝒞^⋆wS⁢(t,t′)Δ𝐷𝐷^𝒞subscript𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′superscript^𝒞⋆subscript𝑤𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′\Delta(D,D(\hat{\cal C}))=\sum_{S(t,t^{\prime})\in\hat{\cal C}^{\star}}w_{S(t,t^{\prime})}roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤\leq≤ ∑S⁢(t,t′)∈𝒞wS⁢(t,t′)=w^subscript𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′𝒞subscript𝑤𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′^𝑤\sum_{S(t,t^{\prime})\in{\cal C}}w_{S(t,t^{\prime})}=\hat{w}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG.

Thus, Δ⁢(D,D⁢(𝒞^))≤w^≤l⁢o⁢g⁢(N)×wo=l⁢o⁢g⁢(N)×Δ⁢(D,D′)Δ𝐷𝐷^𝒞^𝑤𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑁superscript𝑤𝑜𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑁Δ𝐷superscript𝐷′\Delta(D,D(\hat{\cal C}))\leq\hat{w}\leq log(N)\times w^{o}=log(N)\times\Delta(D,D^{\prime})roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) ) ≤ over^ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG ≤ italic_l italic_o italic_g ( italic_N ) × italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_l italic_o italic_g ( italic_N ) × roman_Δ ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), for every LS-fix D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of D𝐷Ditalic_D. □□\Box□

Proof of Theorem 6.1: Based on the tractability results in [12], it suffices to show that the LS-fixes for a database D𝐷Ditalic_D are in one-to-one and polynomial time correspondence with the repairs using tuple deletions [3, 8] for a database D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT wrt a set of key dependencies.

Since we have 1ADs, the violation sets will have a single element, then, for an inconsistent tuple t𝑡titalic_t wrt a constraint 𝑖𝑐∈𝐼𝐶𝑖𝑐𝐼𝐶{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic ∈ IC, it holds ℐ⁢(D,𝑖𝑐,t)={t}ℐ𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑡𝑡{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},t)=\{t\}caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_t ) = { italic_t }. Since all the violation sets are independent, in order to compute an LS-fix for D𝐷Ditalic_D, we have to generate independently all the local fixes t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all inconsistent tuples t𝑡titalic_t such that ({t},𝑖𝑐)∈S⁢(t,t′)𝑡𝑖𝑐𝑆𝑡superscript𝑡′(\{t\},{\it ic})\in S(t,t^{\prime})( { italic_t } , italic_ic ) ∈ italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), with 𝑖𝑐∈𝐼𝐶𝑖𝑐𝐼𝐶{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic ∈ IC; and then combine them in all possible ways.

Those local fixes can be found by considering all the candidate fixes (not necessarily LS-minimal) that can obtained by combining all the possible limits for each attribute provided by the ICs (c.f. Proposition A.0.A.1); and then checking which of them satisfy IC, and finally choosing those that minimize Δ⁢({t},{t′})Δ𝑡superscript𝑡′\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})roman_Δ ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). There are at most 2|ℱ|superscript2ℱ2^{|{\cal F}|}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_F | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT possible candidate fixes, where ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F is the set of fixable attributes.

Let us now define a database D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT consisting of the consistent tuples in D𝐷Ditalic_D together with all the local fixes of the inconsistent tuples. By construction, D𝐷Ditalic_D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT share the same keys. Since each inconsistent tuple in D𝐷Ditalic_D may have more than one local fix, D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT may become inconsistent wrt its key constraints. Each repair for D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, obtained by tuple deletions, will choose one local fix for each inconsistent tuple t𝑡titalic_t of D𝐷Ditalic_D, and therefore will determine an LS-fix of D𝐷Ditalic_D wrt IC. □□\Box□

Proof of Proposition 9:  The 𝑁𝑃𝑁𝑃{\it NP}italic_NP-complete 𝑃𝐴𝑅𝑇𝐼𝑇𝐼𝑂𝑁𝑃𝐴𝑅𝑇𝐼𝑇𝐼𝑂𝑁{\it PARTITION}italic_PARTITION problem [13] can be reduced to this case for a fixed set of 1ADs. Let a A𝐴Aitalic_A be a finite set, whose elements a𝑎aitalic_a have integer sizes s⁢(a)𝑠𝑎s(a)italic_s ( italic_a ). We need to determine if there exists a subset S𝑆Sitalic_S of A𝐴Aitalic_A, such that ∑a∈Ss⁢(a)=n:=(∑a∈As⁢(a))/2subscript𝑎𝑆𝑠𝑎𝑛assignsubscript𝑎𝐴𝑠𝑎2\sum_{a\in S}s(a)=n:=(\sum_{a\in A}s(a))/2∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_a ) = italic_n := ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_a ) ) / 2.

We use two tables: 𝑆𝑒𝑡⁢(𝐸𝑙𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑛𝑡,𝑊𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡)𝑆𝑒𝑡𝐸𝑙𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑛𝑡𝑊𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡{\it Set(Element,Weight)}italic_Set ( italic_Element , italic_Weight ), with key {𝐸𝑙𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑛𝑡,𝑊𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡}𝐸𝑙𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑛𝑡𝑊𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡{\it\{Element,Weight\}}{ italic_Element , italic_Weight }, containing the tuples (a,s⁢(a))𝑎𝑠𝑎(a,s(a))( italic_a , italic_s ( italic_a ) ) for a∈A𝑎𝐴a\in Aitalic_a ∈ italic_A; and 𝑆𝑒𝑙𝑒𝑐𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛⁢(𝐸𝑙𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑛𝑡,X,Y)𝑆𝑒𝑙𝑒𝑐𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛𝐸𝑙𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑛𝑡𝑋𝑌{\it Selection(Element},X,Y)italic_Selection ( italic_Element , italic_X , italic_Y ), with key 𝐸𝑙𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑛𝑡𝐸𝑙𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑛𝑡{\it Element}italic_Element, fixable numerical attributes X,Y𝑋𝑌X,Yitalic_X , italic_Y (the partition of A𝐴Aitalic_A) taking values 00 or 1111 (which can be specified with 1ADs), and initially containing the tuples (a,0,0)𝑎00(a,0,0)( italic_a , 0 , 0 ) for a∈A𝑎𝐴a\in Aitalic_a ∈ italic_A. Finally, we have the 1AD ∀E,X,Y⁢¬⁡(𝑆𝑒𝑙𝑒𝑐𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛⁢(E,X,Y),X<1,Y<1)for-all𝐸𝑋𝑌𝑆𝑒𝑙𝑒𝑐𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛𝐸𝑋𝑌𝑋1𝑌1\forall E,X,Y\neg({\it Selection}(E,X,Y),X<1,Y<1)∀ italic_E , italic_X , italic_Y ¬ ( italic_Selection ( italic_E , italic_X , italic_Y ) , italic_X < 1 , italic_Y < 1 ).

There is a one-to-one correspondence between LS-repairs of the original database and partitions X,Y𝑋𝑌X,Yitalic_X , italic_Y of A𝐴Aitalic_A (collecting the elements with value 1111 in either X𝑋Xitalic_X or Y𝑌Yitalic_Y). Then, there is a partition with the desired property iff the query Q:(Set(E,W),𝑆𝑒𝑙𝑒𝑐𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛(E,X,Y),X=1,𝑠𝑢𝑚(W)=n)Q:~{}(Set(E,W),{\it Selection}(E,X,Y),X=1,{\it sum}(W)=n)italic_Q : ( italic_S italic_e italic_t ( italic_E , italic_W ) , italic_Selection ( italic_E , italic_X , italic_Y ) , italic_X = 1 , italic_sum ( italic_W ) = italic_n )  has answer 𝑦𝑒𝑠𝑦𝑒𝑠{\it yes}italic_yes under the brave semantics. The query used in this proof is acyclic and belongs to the class 𝒞𝑇𝑟𝑒𝑒subscript𝒞𝑇𝑟𝑒𝑒{\cal C}_{\!{\it Tree}}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Tree end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. □□\Box□

For the proof of Theorem 6.2 we need some preliminaries. Let us define a function F𝐹Fitalic_F, with domain 𝒢×S𝒢𝑆{\cal G}\times Scaligraphic_G × italic_S, where 𝒢=⟨𝒱,ℰ⟩𝒢𝒱ℰ{\cal G}=\langle{\cal V},{\cal E}\ranglecaligraphic_G = ⟨ caligraphic_V , caligraphic_E ⟩ is a graph and S𝑆Sitalic_S is a subset of vertexes of graph 𝒢𝒢\cal Gcaligraphic_G, and range non-negative integers. The function is defined as the summation over all the vertices v∈S𝑣𝑆v\in Sitalic_v ∈ italic_S, of cubes of the number of edges connecting v𝑣vitalic_v to vertexes in the complement of S𝑆Sitalic_S.

Definition 12

Given a graph 𝒢=⟨𝒱,ℰ⟩𝒢𝒱ℰ{\cal G}=\langle{\cal V},{\cal E}\ranglecaligraphic_G = ⟨ caligraphic_V , caligraphic_E ⟩ and subset of its vertexes S∈𝒱𝑆𝒱S\in{\cal V}italic_S ∈ caligraphic_V

    Fl⁢(S,v)=|T⁢(S,v)|3superscript𝐹𝑙𝑆𝑣superscript𝑇𝑆𝑣3F^{l}(S,v)=|T(S,v)|^{3}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_v ) = | italic_T ( italic_S , italic_v ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where T⁢(S,v)=𝑇𝑆𝑣absentT(S,v)=italic_T ( italic_S , italic_v ) = {{v′|v′∈(𝒱∖S)∧(v,v′)∈ℰ),v∈S∅,v∉Scasesdelimited-{)conditionalsuperscript𝑣′superscript𝑣′𝒱𝑆𝑣superscript𝑣′ℰ𝑣𝑆𝑣𝑆\left\{\begin{array}[]{cc}\{v^{\prime}|v^{\prime}\in({\cal V}\smallsetminus S)\land(v,v^{\prime})\in{\cal E}),&~{}v\in S\\ \emptyset,&v\not\in S\end{array}\right.{ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL { italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ ( caligraphic_V ∖ italic_S ) ∧ ( italic_v , italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_E ) , end_CELL start_CELL italic_v ∈ italic_S end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ∅ , end_CELL start_CELL italic_v ∉ italic_S end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY
